{{Infobox Sporting Event Organization |name = 1924 Women's Olympiad |image = Flag of United Kingdom.svg |size = 100 px |caption = London, United Kingdom |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = |recurrence = 4 August [[1924 in sports|1924]] |last = |purpose = |headquarters = |leader_title = |leader_name = |website = |remarks = }} [[File:Marguerite Radideau 1930.jpg|thumb|150 px| Marguerite Radideau]] [[File:Mary Lines 1921b.jpg|thumb|150 px| Mary Lines]] [[File:Hilda Hatt 1922b.jpg|thumb|150 px| Hilda Hatt]] [[File:Violette Morris 1920.jpg|thumb|150 px| Violette Morris]] The '''1924 Women's Olympiad''' (formally called ''Women’s International and British Games'',{{cite web |url=http://library.la84.org/OlympicInformationCenter/OlympicReview/1997/oreXXVI15/oreXXVI15u.pdf |title=''DeFrantz, Anita Lucette: The changing role of women in the Olympic Games'' |publisher=Olympic Review, 1997, vol. XXVI, no. 15 June–July, p 18-21 |language=English |accessdate=14 February 2018}} French ''Grand meeting international féminin'') was the first [[Women's World Games|international competition]] for women{{cite web |url=https://books.google.se/books?id=T423AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA155&lpg=PA155&dq=Women%E2%80%99s+Advertising+Club+of+London&source=bl&ots=QVP5wiNWSm&sig=uTEFZzgC8aCuUO-GNoi2P4qZRXw&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj__vSB6rTZAhVQy6QKHd4oCFQQ6AEIbTAJ#v=onepage&q=Women%E2%80%99s%20Advertising%20Club%20of%20London&f=false |title=''Peter Gordon, David Doughan: Dictionary of British Women's Organisations, 1825-1960'' |publisher=Psychology Press 2001 (ISBN 9780713002232), p 156-57 |language=English |accessdate=14 February 2018}} in [[track and field]] in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web |url=https://books.google.se/books?id=vqCJAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA130&lpg=PA130&dq=The+inter+wars+years+Hargreaves&source=bl&ots=CfsRCy1x0H&sig=ezDciu71emewGLSObZDX7fngzec&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjkl-Ts9rTZAhWQ16QKHWSJAJsQ6AEIRDAF#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=''Hargreaves, Jennifer: Sporting Females: Critical Issues in the History and Sociology of Women's Sport'' |publisher=Routledge 1994 (ISBN 9780415070287), p 131-32 |language=English |accessdate=14 February 2018}} The tournament was held{{cite web |url=http://www.asaibrunobonomelli.it/images/files/IL%20VENTRALE.pdf |title=''Giovanni Baldini, Ottavio Castellini, Marco Martini: Il "ventrale" bellezza di un gesto che fu arte prima di essere sport'' |publisher=IAAF 2014, p 59-60 |language=Italian |accessdate=14 February 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/singfreepresswk19240806-1.2.30?ST=1&AT=search&k=the+straits+echo&P=43 |title=''Women's Olympiad'' |publisher=The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser, 6 August 1924 |language=English |accessdate=14 February 2018}} on 4 August{{cite web |url=https://player.bfi.org.uk/free/film/watch-womens-olympiad-1924-online |title=''Women's Olympiad'' |publisher=BFI.org |language=English |accessdate=14 February 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://cdm.athle.com/upload/ssites/001059/jeux_mondiaux_feminins/jmfannee08032017.pdf |title=''Jeux Mondiaux Féminins'' |publisher=Commission documentation et histoire, cdm.athle.com, p 8 |language=French |accessdate=14 February 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/20740522/1625446 |title=''Five world's records'' |publisher=The Brisbane Courier (QLD), August 6, 1924, p 19 |language=English |accessdate=14 February 2018}} 1924{{cite web |url=http://docplayer.fr/4824087-Retrospective-de-l-athletisme-feminin-par-sylvain-charlet.html |title=''Sylvain Charlet: Rétrospective de l'athlétisme féminin'' |publisher=Association des Entraineurs d’Ile de France d’athlétisme (AEIFA) |language=French |accessdate=14 February 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,718976,00.html |title=''Sport: New World's Records'' |publisher= Time.com, Aug. 18. 1924 |language=English |accessdate=14 February 2018}} in [[London]],{{cite web |url=http://www.marathons.fr/Chronique-de-l-athletisme-feminin |title=''Chronique de l'athlétisme féminin'' |publisher=Marathons.fr |language=French |accessdate=14 February 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.sportsmemories.be/photos/1985.Big.jpg |title=''De Vrouwen Meeting Van Londen'' |publisher=Geïllustreerde Sportwereld, N° 174, 16 Augustus 1924 |language=Dutch |accessdate=14 February 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://granville.athle.com/asp.net/espaces.news/news.aspx?id=85755 |title=''Le parcours d’obstacles de l'athlétisme féminin'' |publisher=Granville Athletic Club |language=French |accessdate=14 February 2018}} [[United Kingdom]]. ==Events== After the successful first [[1922 Women's World Games]] in Paris and the three Women's Olympiads ([[1921 Women's Olympiad]], [[1922 Women's Olympiad]] and [[1923 Women's Olympiad]]) in Monaco the interest for [[women's sports]] also grew internationally. In 1922 the "[[Women's Amateur Athletic Association]]" (WAAA) was founded in the UK: the WAAA organised the first official British women championships in track and field ([[1923 WAAA Championships|WAAA Championships]]) on 18 August [[1923 in sports|1923]] at the Oxo Sports Ground in [[Downham, London|Downham]] outside London. In the US the "[[Amateur Athletic Union]]" (AAU) organised the [[1923 USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships|first official American women championships in track and field]] on 29 September 1923 at [[Weequahic Park]] in [[Newark, New Jersey]]. The 1924 Women's Olympiad was organised in cooperation with the newspapers [[News of the World]], [[Sporting Life (British newspaper)|Sporting Life]] and [[Daily Mirror]] in cooperation with the WAAA and the [[Fédération Sportive Féminine Internationale]] (FSFI) under chairwoman [[Alice Milliat]]. The games were attended by participants from 8 nations: Belgium, Canada (exhibition events only), Czechoslovakia, France, Italy, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the USA (exhibition events only). The tournament was a huge promotion for women's sports. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !Team !Nation !Participants |- | '''1''' |align=left| {{BEL}} | ? |- | '''2''' |align=left| {{flag|Canada|1921}} | ? |- | '''3''' |align=left| {{CSK}} | ? |- | '''4''' |align=left| {{FRA}} | ? |- | '''5''' |align=left| {{flag|Italy|1861}} | ? |- | '''6''' |align=left| {{CHE}} | ? |- | '''7''' |align=left| {{GBR}} | ? |- | '''8''' |align=left| {{flag|USA|1912}} | ? |} The athletes{{cite web |url=http://www.gbrathletics.com/wrb.htm |title=''World records set in Britain'' |publisher=GBR Athletics.com |language=English |accessdate=14 February 2018}} competed in 12 events: [[Sprint (running)|running]] ([[100-yard dash|100 yards]], 250 metres, [[1000 metres]], [[Relay race]] 4 x 110 yards and 4 x 220 yards and [[Hurdling|120 yards]], [[Racewalking]] 1000 metres, [[high jump]], [[long jump]], [[discus throw]], [[shot put]] and [[javelin]]. The tournament also held exhibition events in [[cycling]] (two-thirds of a mile bicycle sprint), [[netball]] and [[gymnastics]]. The [[multi-sport event]] was held at "[[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]]" in [[Fulham]] in southwest London. The games attended an audience of 25,000 spectators. ==Results== Almost all medals went to athletes from France and the United Kingdom. During the games 7 world records were set: Mary Lines in hurdling 120 yd and running 250 m, Edith Trickey in running 1000 m, Albertine Regel in walking 1000 m, Elise van Truyen in high jump, Violett Morris in discus and Louise Groslimond in javelin. Poorly performed measuring however led to that only 2 records, Trickey in [[1000 metres world record progression#Women|running 1000 metres]] and Regel in walking 1000 metres, later were ratified. Results in each event: {| {{MedalistTable|type=Event|columns=2}} |- |'''100 yds''' | '''[[Rose Thompson]]'''

|| |- |} *{{note label|nb|nb|nb}} Each athlete in the shot put and javelin throw events threw using their right hand, then their left. Their final mark was the total of the best mark with their right-handed throw and the best mark with their left-handed throw. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !Team !Nation !Points |- | '''1''' |align=left| {{GBR}} | 61 |- | '''2''' |align=left| {{FRA}} | 31 |- | '''3''' |align=left| {{BEL}} | 15 |- | '''4''' |align=left| {{CSK}} | 13 |- | '''5''' |align=left| {{CHE}} | 7 |- | '''6''' |align=left| {{flag|Italy|1861}} | ? |} ==Legacy== The tournament was a huge promotion for women's sports, a follow-up was held in 1925 (”Daily Mirror Trophy”) also at Stamford Bridge. In [[1926 Women's World Games|1926]] the second regular [[Women's World Games]] were held at Gothenburg. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commonscat|Women's World Games}} ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tp7jv3zjMEU Film 1924 Women's Olympiad, Topical Budget (YouTube)] * [https://player.bfi.org.uk/free/film/watch-womens-olympiad-1924-online Film 1924 Women's Olympiad (British Film Institute)] {{Women's World Games}} [[Category:Multi-sport events in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:International sports competitions hosted by the United Kingdom]] [[Category:International athletics competitions hosted by the United Kingdom]] [[Category:International sports competitions hosted by London]] [[Category:1924 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1924 in multi-sport events]] [[Category:1924 in athletics (track and field)|Women's Olympiad]] [[Category:1924 in sports]] [[Category:1924 in women's athletics]] [[Category:History of sport in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1924 in English sport]] [[Category:1924 in London]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name =ANZ National Stadium | nickname = | image =ANZ Stadium Fiji.jpg | caption =ANZ Stadium | fullname = | location = {{Flagicon|Fiji}} [[Suva]], [[Fiji]] | coordinates ={{Coord|18|9|0|S|178|26|57|E|display=inline,title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} | broke_ground = | built =1951 | opened = | renovated =1978–1979
2012–2013 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Government of [[Suva]] City | operator = Government of [[Suva]] City | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants =[[Suva Highlanders]]
[[Suva F.C.|Suva FC]]
[[Fiji national football team]] | seating_capacity =4,300 (stadium seating)
15,000 (total with embankments) | dimensions = }} The '''ANZ National Stadium''' (known as '''ANZ Stadium'''){{cite news|last=Kumar|first=Rashneel|title=New stadium ready for Flying Fijians|url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=233335|date=8 May 2013|newspaper=[[Fiji Times]]|location=Suva, Fiji |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108225600/http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=233335 |archivedate=2014-11-08}} is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Suva]], [[Fiji]]. ANZ Stadium is used primarily for [[rugby league]], [[rugby union]] and [[football (soccer)|football]] matches, and features a track as well as a pitch suitable for worldwide competition. It has undercover seating for 4,000 spectators, and concrete and grass embankments that increase the capacity to 15,000 people.{{cite web |author=Fiji Sports Council |title=Facilities |date=10 July 2014 |url=http://www.fijisportscouncil.com.fj/index.php/facilities |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426031517/http://www.fijisportscouncil.com.fj/index.php/facilities |archivedate=2016-04-26 }} ==Construction and renovations== Originally called Buckhurst Park, the stadium was constructed in 1951 on sixteen hectares of land given by William H. B. Buckhurst in 1948.{{cite web |title=Rotary Club of Suva, Fiji, First Club of the South Pacific Islands |work=Rotary Global History Fellowship |url=https://www.rghfhome.org/first100/global/countries/fiji/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424200434/https://www.rghfhome.org/first100/global/countries/fiji/ |archivedate=2016-04-24 |accessdate=18 April 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://library.la84.org/OlympicInformationCenter/RevueOlympique/1979/orf143/orf143p.pdf |title=Les Iles Fidji et l'Olympisme |language=French |work=LA84 Foundation |accessdate=11 April 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304044155/http://library.la84.org/OlympicInformationCenter/RevueOlympique/1979/orf143/orf143p.pdf |archivedate=2016-03-04 }} The stadium was first renovated in 1978–1979 for the [[1979 South Pacific Games|Sixth South Pacific Games]].{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsportspulse.com/assoc_page.cgi?client=1-2689-0-0-0&sID=121642&&news_task=DETAIL&articleID=8634422 |accessdate = 3 June 2014 | title = South Pacific Games 1979 - Fiji |work=Solomon Islands Games Record |publisher=Fox Sports Pulse |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303194222/http://www.foxsportspulse.com/assoc_page.cgi?client=1-2689-0-0-0&sID=121642&&news_task=DETAIL&articleID=8634422 |archivedate=2016-03-03 }} Work commenced in April 1978 with the demolition of the grandstand, which had lost its roof during [[Cyclone Bebe|Hurricane Bebe]].{{cite news |url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=237617 |title=Sporting history begins |newspaper=[[Fiji Times]] |first=Frederica |last=Elbourne |date=22 June 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414115314/http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=237617 |archivedate=2015-04-14 }} The stadium was renamed National Stadium upon reopening in 1979. A second renovation took place in 2012, sponsored by [[ANZ Fiji]], Fiji's largest bank, at a cost of FJD $17.5 million.{{cite news |title=$17.5m For Stadium Upgrade |date=9 August 2012 |first=Anasilini |last=Ratuva |newspaper=[[Fiji Sun]] |url=http://fijisun.com.fj/2012/08/09/17-5m-for-stadium-upgrade/ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426033904/http://fijisun.com.fj/2012/08/09/17-5m-for-stadium-upgrade/ |archivedate=2016-04-26 }} The stadium reopened in March 2013, with a rugby union game between the [[Fiji national rugby union team|Fiji national team]] and [[Classic All Blacks]]. ==Buckhurst and Bidesi Parks== The 2012–2013 renovation also included the park and playing grounds behind the ANZ National Stadium, which are known as Bidesi Park and Buckhurst Park, retaining the stadium's original name. The Buckhurst and Bidesi grounds include three pitches primarily used for training and competition in rugby, rugby league, football, and cricket, and a small stadium and synthetic training track. Buckhurst Park was the site of the National Baseball Diamond used in the [[2003 South Pacific Games]].{{cite web |title=Buckhurst Baseball Ground – Competition Venue |date=29 June 2003 |publisher=Fox Sports Pulse |work=2003 South Pacific Games |url=http://www.foxsportspulse.com/assoc_page.cgi?client=0-1992-0-0-0&sID=15068&&news_task=DETAIL&articleID=39587 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426035523/http://www.foxsportspulse.com/assoc_page.cgi?client=0-1992-0-0-0&sID=15068&&news_task=DETAIL&articleID=39587 |archivedate=2016-04-26 }} ==International Soccer Matches== {| class="wikitable" ! Date !! Competition!! Team !! Res !! Team |- | 5 Sep 2018 | International Friendly | {{fb|FIJ}} | align=center |1-1 | {{fb|SOL}} |} ==See also== {{Portal|Rugby league}} *[[List of rugby league stadiums by capacity]] *[[List of rugby union stadiums by capacity]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Fiji national rugby union team}} {{NRC Grounds}} {{Super Rugby stadiums}} [[Category:Fiji national rugby union team]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Fiji]] [[Category:Football venues in Fiji]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Fiji]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Fiji]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Fiji]] [[Category:National stadiums|Fiji]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Fiji]] [[Category:Suva]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1951]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1979]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2013]]

{{Infobox stadium |name = Al Lang Stadium |nickname = |image = Image:Rowdies Soccer Config 2015.jpg |caption = Al Lang Stadium in 2015 |coordinates = {{coord|27.7681|-82.6331|type:landmark_region:US-FL|display=inline,title}} |location = 180 2nd Avenue SE
[[St. Petersburg, Florida]] 33701 |broke_ground = |opened = 1947 |renovated = 1976, 1996, 2015 |closed = |demolished = |owner = [[St. Petersburg, Florida|City of St. Petersburg]] |operator = Big 3 Entertainment |surface = [[Grass]] |construction_cost = [[USD|$]]300,000{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/sports/baseball/rays/article435261.ece|title=St. Petersburg bids farewell to lovely lady by bay|last=Hayes|first=Stephanie|date=March 28, 2008|website=Tampa Bay Times|accessdate=2017-01-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315201349/http://www.tampabay.com/sports/baseball/rays/article435261.ece|archive-date=2012-03-15|dead-url=yes|df=}} (original) |architect = |former_names = Florida Power Park, Progress Energy Park |tenants = [[New York Yankees]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) ([[spring training]]) (1947–1950, 1952–1961)
[[St. Louis Cardinals]] (MLB) (spring training) (1947–1997)
[[St. Petersburg Saints]] ([[Florida International League|FIL]]/[[Florida State League|FSL]]) (1947–1965)
[[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] (MLB) (spring training) (1951){{cite news |title=Major Leaguers to Start Spring Training Feb. 20 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=69EOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=e1UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4394,6411752&dq=new-york-giants+st+petersburg |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120713185525/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=69EOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=e1UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4394,6411752&dq=new-york-giants+st+petersburg |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 13, 2012 |newspaper=The Evening Independent |page=14|publisher= |date=January 19, 1951 |accessdate=2017-01-04}}
[[New York Mets]] (MLB) (spring training) (1962–1987)
[[St. Petersburg Pelicans]] ([[Senior Professional Baseball Association|SPBA]]) (1989–1990)
[[St. Petersburg Cardinals]] (FSL) (1965–1997)
[[Baltimore Orioles]] (MLB) (spring training) (1991–1995)
[[St. Petersburg Devil Rays]] (FSL) (1998–2000)
[[Tampa Bay Rays|Tampa Bay Devil Rays/Rays]] (MLB) (spring training) (1998–2008)
[[Tampa Bay Rowdies]] ([[USL Championship|USLC]]) (2011–present)
[[Tampa Bay Rowdies|Tampa Bay Rowdies U23]] ([[USL League Two|USL2]]) (2017–present; some games) |seating_capacity = 7,227{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/teams/united-states/fc-tampa-bay-rowdies/14861/venue/|title=Tampa Bay Rowdies – Al Lang Stadium|website=SoccerWay|accessdate=2017-01-04}} | dimensions = 110 x 75yd }} '''Al Lang Stadium'''{{cite web|url=http://www.rowdiessoccer.com/index.php?id=556|title=Al Lang Stadium|last=|first=|date=|website=rowdiessoccer.com|publisher=Tampa Bay Rowdies|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014071951/http://www.rowdiessoccer.com/index.php?id=556|archive-date=October 14, 2012|access-date=2017-01-04}} is a 7,500-seat sports [[stadium]] in downtown [[St. Petersburg, Florida]] that is the current home pitch of the [[Tampa Bay Rowdies]] of the [[United Soccer League]] (USL). It was used almost exclusively as a [[baseball park]] for over 60 years. However, since the Rowdies moved to the facility in 2011, it has been reconfigured to better host soccer. Al Lang Stadium was built in 1947 at the site of an older facility known as St. Petersburg Athletic Park. It is named in honor of [[Al Lang]], a former mayor of St. Petersburg who was instrumental in bringing minor league and spring training baseball to the city in the early 20th century.{{cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/remembering-al-lang-st-petersburgs-mr-baseball/428340|title=Remembering Al Lang, St. Petersburg's Mr. Baseball|first=Melanie|date=March 22, 2008|work=Tampa Bay Times|first2=Curtis|location=St. Petersburg, Florida|via=|accessdate=2017-01-04|author1=Ave|author2=Krueger|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818043647/http://www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/remembering-al-lang-st-petersburgs-mr-baseball/428340|archive-date=2016-08-18|dead-url=yes|df=}} The ballpark was reconstructed in 1976 and was extensively renovated before the [[Tampa Bay Rays|Tampa Bay Devil Rays]] began using it as their first [[spring training]] venue in 1998. The Devil Rays / Rays were the last of a long series of [[Major League Baseball]] clubs to conduct spring training and host an affiliated [[Minor League Baseball|minor league team]] at Al Lang Stadium and St. Petersburg's previous ballparks. Before the Rays, tenants included the [[New York Yankees]], [[St. Louis Cardinals]], [[New York Mets]], and the [[Baltimore Orioles]], amongst others. The stadium hosted its last spring training game in March 2008 and was the site of occasional amateur and exhibition baseball for the next several years. The Tampa Bay Rowdies became the primary tenant in 2011, and Al Lang Stadium was incrementally modified into a better soccer venue over each of the following off-seasons. Since October 2014, an agreement between the club and the city of St. Petersburg has made the stadium a soccer-only facility, and the Rowdies' ownership conducted an extensive renovation in early 2015. In 2016, Rowdies' majority owner [[Bill Edwards (businessman)|Bill Edwards]] proposed greatly expanding the stadium's capacity to 18,000 seats as part of a bid to move his club into [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS). In May 2017, a local [[referendum]] passed authorizing the city of St. Petersburg to negotiate a long-term lease with the team to help make the project possible.{{Cite web|url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2017/05/florida_al_lang_stadium_expansion_approved_by_voters|title=Florida: Al Lang Stadium expansion approved by voters|last=|first=|date=|website=Stadium DB|language=en|via=[[Tampa Bay Times]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 12, 2018}} In October 2018, the Rowdies were purchased by the [[Tampa Bay Rays]], which gave the baseball club control of Al Lang Stadium through the transfer of the existing lease with the city of St. Petersburg.{{cite news |last1=Muellner |first1=Alexis |title=Rowdies owner Bill Edwards talks about how the Rays deal came together |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/news/2018/10/02/behind-the-deal-rowdies-owner-bill-edwards-talks.html |accessdate=2 October 2018 |work=Tampa Bay Business Journal |date=2 October 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wtsp.com/mobile/article/sports/the-tampa-bay-rays-are-buying-the-tampa-bay-rowdies-control-of-al-lang-stadium/599741826|title=The Tampa Bay Rays are buying the Tampa Bay Rowdies, control of Al Lang Stadium|last=Pransky|first=Noah|date=October 1, 2018|work=[[WTSP]]|access-date=November 12, 2018|last2=Zimmer|first2=Beau|language=en-US}} ==History== ===Background=== {{see also|Baseball in the Tampa Bay Area}} Professional baseball grew throughout the United States at the beginning of the twentieth century, and clubs sought additional facilities to accommodate their [[spring training]]. [[Al Lang]], a businessman in [[St. Petersburg, Florida]], saw a huge potential to attract northeastern teams to his city to take advantage of the warm weather during the early months of the year. Lang and city officials created an incentives package that covered teams' travel expenses and other amenities, which drew in the city's first spring training tenant, the [[St. Louis Browns]], in 1914. The club trained at [[Coffee Pot Park]], a small ballpark located beside Coffee Pot bayou about a mile north of the current site of Al Lang Stadium. Subsequently, other [[Major League Baseball]] clubs such as the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] and the [[New York Yankees]] came to St. Petersburg for spring training, and Lang continued promoting the city when he was elected Mayor of St. Petersburg in 1916. After his term, Lang devoted his life to building a successful connection between Florida and baseball, and was instrumental in marketing St. Petersburg as a desirable sports site.Fountain, Charles (2009) ''Under the March Sun: The Story of Spring Training.'' New York: Oxford University Press, pages 23-32. With Al Lang's support, the city replaced Coffee Pot Park with St. Petersburg Athletic Park (also known as Waterfront Park) on the present site of Al Lang Stadium in [[1923 in baseball|1923]]. It served as the spring training home for Major League Baseball teams the [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]] and the [[New York Yankees]] until after World War II, hosting baseball greats such as [[Babe Ruth]], [[Lou Gehrig]], [[Joe DiMaggio]], and [[Stan Musial]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2008/02/10/Rays/All_Time_Spring_Team.shtml|title=Rays: All-Time Spring Team|last=Topkin|first=Marc|date=February 10, 2008|website=Tampa Bay Times|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-04}} [[File:Al Lang grandstand.jpg|right|thumb|The grandstand at Al Lang Stadium]] ===Current stadium=== In 1947, the city of St. Petersburg demolished Waterfront Park and constructed a modern baseball park on the same site. It was named Al Lang Stadium in honor of his many years of service to the city and his continual promotion of baseball in the area. The [[St. Louis Cardinals]] and [[New York Yankees]] shared the new ballpark in its first spring training season. The stadium underwent a major reconstruction in 1976, expanding its capacity to 7,227.Moncada, Carlos (August 28, 2006. [http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=113E09E635C70378&p_docnum=2&p_queryname=1 S"t. Petersburg Considering Life Without Al Lang Field" ''The Tampa Tribune''. Retrieved May 13, 2014.]{{Better source|date=January 2017}} It was renovated again in 1996; the project cost $640,117 and included disability accommodations.Chick, Bob (March 1, 1996) [http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0EB0F5BDCA4DDB12&p_docnum=1&p_queryname=1 "Al Lang enjoys being pampered after 20 years"]. ''The Tampa Tribune''. Accessed May 13, 2014.{{Better source|date=January 2017}} When the expansion Tampa Bay Devil Rays began using the park for spring training in 1998, local utility [[Florida Power]] purchased the park's naming rights for $150,000 per year, and the city rechristened it Florida Power Park at Al Lang Field.{{Cite web|url=http://sec.edgar-online.com/fpc-capital-i/def-14a-proxy-statement-definitive/1998/03/12/Section10.aspx|title=FPC CAPITAL I - FPC.A Proxy Statement (definitive) (DEF 14A) Compensation of Directors|last=|first=|date=March 12, 1998|website=sec.edgar-online.com|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509193949/http://sec.edgar-online.com/fpc-capital-i/def-14a-proxy-statement-definitive/1998/03/12/Section10.aspx|dead-url=yes|archive-date=May 9, 2012|access-date=2017-01-04}} When Florida Power was acquired by [[Progress Energy Inc|Progress Energy]] in 2003, the stadium's name was changed to Progress Energy Park.{{Cite web|url=http://www.progress-energy.com/aboutus/news/article.asp?id=4882|title=CP&L and Florida Power officially re-branded Progress Energy as of Jan. 1|last=|first=|date=January 2, 2003|website=progress-energy.com|publisher=Progress Energy|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026161419/http://www.progress-energy.com/aboutus/news/article.asp?id=4882|archive-date=October 26, 2008|access-date=2017-01-04}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2002/10/03/Business/Lights_out_for_Florid.shtml|title=Lights out for Florida Power name|last=Hau|first=Louis|date=October 3, 2002|website=St. Petersburg Times|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-04}} The naming rights agreement expired in 2011, and the facility's name reverted to Al Lang Stadium. ====Description==== Al Lang Stadium's grandstand faces the southeast, giving almost every seat a view of the St. Petersburg harbor and [[Tampa Bay]] beyond the left field wall. The stadium is constructed primarily of [[reinforced concrete]], and the public portions of the facility include very few enclosed and air conditioned areas. A unique concrete [[cantilever]]ed overhang shades many of the grandstand seats from the afternoon sun, and the stadium's waterfront location is often cooled by a [[sea breeze]]. During the 2015 renovation, the Rowdies replaced all of the seats in the grandstand, refreshed fan areas under the grandstand, and extensively updated many of the club and gameday operation areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/slideshow/2015/02/13/exclusive-take-a-tour-of-the-al-lang-stadium.html|title=Take a tour of the Al Lang Stadium renovations with Tampa Bay Rowdies owner|first=Alexis|date=February 13, 2013|website=Tampa Bay Business Journal|publisher=|accessdate=2017-01-04|author=Muellner}} In addition, a portion of the outfield wall was removed and two banks of uncovered bleachers installed in its place, adding several hundred seats on the sideline of the soccer pitch opposite the grandstand. ==Tenants and events== [[File:Al lang - last pitch.JPG|thumb|Baseball at the stadium - last pitch of the final spring game on March 28, 2008]] ===Baseball=== Al Lang stadium has hosted may thousand [[spring training|major league spring training]], [[minor league baseball|minor league]], college, high school, international. and exhibition baseball games over the decades. ====Professional baseball==== Al Lang Stadium was originally built as a spring training and minor league venue and served that purpose from 1947 until 2008. Spring training tenants included the [[New York Yankees]], [[St. Louis Cardinals]], [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]], [[New York Mets]], and [[Baltimore Orioles]]. Minor league tenants included the [[St. Petersburg Saints]] of the [[Florida International League]] and the [[St. Petersburg Cardinals]] of the [[Florida State League]]. Al Lang Stadium's final minor league tenant was the [[Class A (baseball)|Class A]] [[St. Petersburg Devil Rays]], who last played at the stadium in [[2000 in baseball|2000]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/071800/TampaBay/Deal_to_sell__Baby_Ra.shtml|title=Tampabay: Deal to sell 'Baby Rays' wrapped up|last=Gilmer|first=Byran|date=July 18, 2000|website=St. Petersburg Times|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-04}} In 1998, the expansion [[Tampa Bay Devil Rays]] began using the stadium for spring training. Their regular season home at [[Tropicana Field]] is approximately one mile west, making the Devil Rays the first major league team to train and play regular season games in the same city in almost 90 years. In 2006, the Rays, seeking to expand their fan base across the [[Tampa Bay area]], decided to move their spring training operations to [[Charlotte Sports Park]] in [[Port Charlotte, Florida]], about 80 miles south of St. Petersburg.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/08/16/news_pf/Southpinellas/If_Rays_go__Al_Lang_c.shtml|title=If Rays go, Al Lang could be reduced to memories|last=Sharockman|first=Aaron|date=August 16, 2006|website=St. Petersburg Times|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-04}} They played their last spring training ballgame at Al Lang Stadium on March 28, 2008.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/st-petersburg-to-see-its-final-spring-training-game-friday-after-94-years/428725|title=St. Petersburg to see its final spring training game Friday after 94 years|last=Sharockman|first=Aaron|date=March 23, 2008|website=Tampa Bay Times|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819143943/http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/st-petersburg-to-see-its-final-spring-training-game-friday-after-94-years/428725|archive-date=2016-08-19|dead-url=yes|df=}} ====Amateur baseball==== [[Baseball in the Tampa Bay area]] has a long history, and amateur baseball has long been played in Al Lang Stadium and its predecessors in downtown St. Petersburg. Many different tournament, exhibition, practice, and regular season games have been held there, with the [[University of South Florida St. Petersburg]] club baseball program the last amateur team to call Al Lang Stadium home during their inaugural season of 2014. The [[1997 Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament|1997]] and [[2002 Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament|2002]] [[Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament]]s were played at the venue,{{cite web |url=http://www.theacc.com/sports/m-basebl/2012-acc-baseball-guide.html |title=2012 ACC Baseball Guide |last= |first= |date= |publisher= |work=TheACC.com |accessdate=2012-05-29 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/682OROOXc?url=http://www.theacc.com/sports/m-basebl/2012-acc-baseball-guide.html |archivedate=May 30, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} as was the [[2000 Conference USA Baseball Tournament|2000]] [[Conference USA Baseball Tournament]].{{cite web |url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/c-usa/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/2011-12/misc_non_event/c-usa-m-basebl-guide-2012.pdf |title=2012 Conference USA Baseball Media Guide |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher= |page=75 |accessdate=2012-06-21 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68aqThrrz?url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/c-usa/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/2011-12/misc_non_event/c-usa-m-basebl-guide-2012.pdf |archivedate=June 21, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} From 2010 to 2014, Al Lang Stadium hosted the St. Petersburg International Baseball Series, which involved international teams, national teams, and local college and high school teams along with minor league squads from various major league organizations that were already in the area for spring training.{{Cite web|url=http://www.stpeteinternationalbaseball.com/index.php|title=2016 Schedule|last=|first=|date=|website=StPeteInternationalBaseball.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-04}}{{Better source|date=January 2017}} The event moved to other local venues in 2015. After the Tampa Bay Rowdies moved to Al Lang Stadium in 2011, the playing surface and seating arrangement had to be constantly alternated between baseball and soccer configurations, especially in the spring. The resulting poor condition of the turf led to complaints by Rowdies management and, in October 2014, an agreement that baseball would not be played at the facility.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/edwards-to-city-fix-al-lang-field-or-the-rowdies-may-have-to-move/2179047 |title=Edwards to city: Fix Al Lang field or the Rowdies may have to move |last=Snow Smith |first=Katherine |date=May 9, 2014 |website=Tampa Bay Times |publisher= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512014031/http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/edwards-to-city-fix-al-lang-field-or-the-rowdies-may-have-to-move/2179047 |archive-date=May 12, 2014 |access-date=2017-01-04 |deadurl=yes }} ===Soccer=== In 2011, the soccer team [[FC Tampa Bay]] of the [[North American Soccer League]] announced it would move to Al Lang Stadium from [[George M. Steinbrenner Field]] in Tampa.{{cite news |author = |date= March 9, 2011 |title= Mainsail Suites, Lotto among FC Tampa Bay 2011 season sponsors |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/news/2011/03/09/mainsail-suites-lotto-among-fc-tampa.html |newspaper= Tampa Bay Business Journal|location= |publisher= |accessdate= November 18, 2013}} This ended three years in which the stadium had no long-term tenant. Al Lang Stadium subsequently underwent minor renovations to convert it into a soccer facility, with temporary seats added on the grass along the sidelines to increase capacity.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasl.com/index.php?id=3&newsid=119|title=FCTB To Play At Al Lang Stadium|last=|first=|date=January 17, 2011|website=nasl.com|publisher=North American Soccer League|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110423095633/http://www.nasl.com/index.php?id=3&newsid=119|archive-date=April 23, 2011|access-date=2017-01-04}}{{Cite web|url=http://nasl.com/index.php?id=3&newsid=64|title=Al Lang Stadium Transitioning To FCTB Home|last=|first=|date=February 25, 2011|website=nasl.com|publisher=North American Soccer League|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110423100536/http://www.nasl.com/index.php?id=3&newsid=64|archive-date=April 23, 2011|access-date=2017-01-04}} The team played its first game at Al Lang on April 9, 2011, and later changed its name to the Tampa Bay Rowdies, after the [[Tampa Bay Rowdies (1975–93)|historical team]] that had played from 1975 to 1993.{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/al-lang-stadium-s974/|title=A Kick in the Grass|last=Dietrich|first=Jim|date=|website=Stadium Journey|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120709083351/http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/al-lang-stadium-s974|archive-date=July 9, 2012|access-date=2017-01-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.insidemnsoccer.com/2010/01/29/tampa-bay-rowdies-change-name-to-fc-tampa-bay/|title=Tampa Bay Rowdies Change Name to FC Tampa Bay|last=Quarstad|first=Brian|date=January 29, 2010|website=Insidemnsoccer.com|publisher=|accessdate=2017-01-04}} On October 27, 2012, the Tampa Bay Rowdies became the [[2012 North American Soccer League season|2012 NASL Champions]] by winning the two-leg [[Soccer Bowl]] against the [[Minnesota Stars]] at Al Lang Stadium. It was the first time that a major championship was held at the site.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasl.com/index.php?id=3&newsid=3473|title=Tampa Bay Wins NASL Championship Series After Penalty Shootout|last=|first=|date=October 27, 2013|website=nasl.com|publisher=North American Soccer League|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013102719/http://www.nasl.com/index.php?id=3&newsid=3473|archive-date=October 13, 2013|access-date=2017-01-04}} In 2013, the Rowdies signed a lease extension keeping the team at Al Lang Stadium through the 2016 season.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rowdiessoccer.com/index.php?id=52&newsid=3231|title=Rowdies Agree To Stadium Deal At Al Lang Stadium|last=|first=|date=September 12, 2012|website=rowdiessoccer.com|publisher=Rowdies Soccer|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224044649/http://rowdiessoccer.com/index.php?id=52&newsid=3231|archive-date=February 24, 2013|access-date=2017-01-04}} In 2014, Rowdies majority owner Bill Edwards publicly complained that the city of St. Petersburg and the St. Petersburg Baseball Commission, which managed Al Lang Stadium, had not kept up with maintenance on the grandstand, the locker rooms, or the playing field. This was partially due to the fact that although the Rowdies have been the only regular tenant of Al Lang Stadium since 2011, it was regularly used for exhibition and amateur baseball during the spring, necessitating that the playing surface be converted for soccer use by removing the pitcher's mound and replacing the infield dirt with grass.{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/sports/soccer/fc-tampa-bay-to-call-al-lang-home-for-two-seasons/1146358|title=FC Tampa Bay to call Al Lang home for two seasons – St. Petersburg Times|last=A. Encina|first=Eduardo|date=January 19, 2011|website=Tampa Bay Times|publisher=|accessdate=2017-01-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016203835/http://www.tampabay.com/sports/soccer/fc-tampa-bay-to-call-al-lang-home-for-two-seasons/1146358|archive-date=2012-10-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{Cite web|url=http://tbtpics.tampabay.com/news/business/tampa-bay-rowdies-fans-complain-about-al-lang-stadium/2174889|title=Tampa Bay Rowdies fans complain about Al Lang Stadium|last=Phippen|first=Weston|date=April 12, 2014|website=Tampa Bay Times|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304112713/http://tbtpics.tampabay.com/news/business/tampa-bay-rowdies-fans-complain-about-al-lang-stadium/2174889|archive-date=March 4, 2016|access-date=2017-01-04}} The dispute resulted in the Rowdies filing a lawsuit against the St. Petersburg Baseball Commission in July 2014 claiming that the commission was not properly maintaining the "dilapidated" facility.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/bill-edwards-sues-baseball-commission-over-al-lang-stadium/2187000|title=Bill Edwards sues baseball commission over Al Lang Stadium|last=Stanley|first=Kameel|date=July 2, 2014|website=Tampa Bay Times|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304103337/http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/bill-edwards-sues-baseball-commission-over-al-lang-stadium/2187000|archive-date=March 4, 2016|access-date=2017-01-04}} ====Transfer of stadium management==== The issues were finally resolved in October 2014 when Edwards and the city of St. Petersburg brokered a deal that gave Edwards' Big 3 Entertainment company management control of Al Lang Stadium for the next four years. As part of the arrangement, the facility would no longer be used for baseball events, and Edwards agreed to complete $1.5 million in renovations as he sought to make Al Lang Stadium more soccer friendly.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/its-official-bill-edwards-will-control-al-lang-stadium-in-a-deal-approved/2200447|title=St. Petersburg City Council gives developer Bill Edwards control of Al Lang Stadium|last=Stanley|first=Kameel|date=October 2, 2014|website=Tampa Bay Times|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304111304/http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/its-official-bill-edwards-will-control-al-lang-stadium-in-a-deal-approved/2200447|archive-date=March 4, 2016|access-date=2017-01-04}} ===Other sports=== ====Lacrosse==== On January 29, 2013 [[Major League Lacrosse]] announced that the 2012 MLL champions the [[Rochester Rattlers]] would face the [[Chesapeake Bayhawks]] for their season opener at Al Lang stadium. It would be the first time that the league would play there. Part of this game is an effort to evaluate the [[Tampa Bay Area]], and the state of [[Florida]] in general, for an expansion team, after MLL held the [[Major League Lacrosse All-Star Game|All-Star game]] at [[FIU Stadium]] the previous year. It was supported by the St. Petersburg/Clearwater Sports Commission who want to affirm the city's brand as a world-class destination for sports tourism.{{cite web|url=http://www.majorleaguelacrosse.com/press-release/6737/rochester-rattlers-to-face-2012-mll-champion-chesapeake-bayhawks-in-st-petersburg-fla-on-april-27|title=Rochester Rattlers to face 2012 MLL Champion Chesapeake Bayhawks in St. Petersburg, Fla. on April 27|last=MLL Communications|first=|date=March 18, 2016|website=|publisher=Major League Lacrosse|access-date=2017-01-04}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2013-01-29/sports/bal-mll-chesapeake-bayhawks-rochester-rattlers-to-play-regular-season-at-al-lang-stadium-20130129_1_professional-lacrosse-bayhawks-mll|title=Bayhawks, Rattlers to play regular-season game at Al Lang Stadium|last=|first=|date=January 29, 2013|work=|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|via=|accessdate=2017-01-04}} The game was played on Saturday, April 27, 2013 in front of 3,940 people (a figure higher than half the league's average attendance),{{cite web|url=http://mll.stats.pointstreak.com/attendance.html?leagueid=323&seasonid=8519|title=League Attendance|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Major League Lacrosse|access-date=2017-01-04}} with Chesapeake winning, 17–14.{{cite web|url=http://www.majorleaguelacrosse.com/press-release/7231/dixon-leads-bayhawks-to-opening-1714-win/|title=Dixon Leads Bayhawks to Opening 17-14 Win|last=MLL Communications|first=|date=March 18, 2014|website=|publisher=Major League Lacrosse|access-date=2017-01-04}} ==== Rugby ==== In 2015, Al Lang Stadium hosted the Halloween Rugby 7s, a rugby sevens tournament featuring eight teams: USA Falcons, USA Hawks, Canada, Argentina, Denver, New York City, Ohio and Utah.{{Cite web|url=http://www.halloweenrugby7s.com/|title=Scary Fast, Fit & Furious|last=|first=|date=|website=halloweenrugby7s.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160625144643/http://www.halloweenrugby7s.com/|archivedate=June 25, 2016|df=}} ==Future== ===Proposed Rays ballpark=== In [[2006 in baseball|2006]], the [[Tampa Bay Rays]] announced plans to move their spring training home to [[Port Charlotte, Florida|Port Charlotte]], about 80 minutes south of St. Petersburg, for the 2009 season. In November 2007, Rays President Matt Silverman introduced a plan to build a $450 million new [[Rays Ballpark]] at the Al Lang Stadium site that was to be ready for the 2012 baseball season. The plan failed to garner enough political support to move forward, and it was shelved in June 2008.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/rays-president-optimistic-about-baseball-in-bay-area/649945|title=Rays president optimistic about baseball in bay area|last=Sharockman|first=Aaron|date=June 28, 2008|website=Tampa Bay Times|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803174625/http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/rays-president-optimistic-about-baseball-in-bay-area/649945|archive-date=2016-08-03|dead-url=yes|df=}} Subsequently, the Rays began looking at other potential locations, and in May 2009, they announced that they would not seek to build a new facility in downtown St. Petersburg.{{cite web|url=http://rays.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090522&content_id=4890804&vkey=news_tb&fext=.jsp&c_id=tb|title=St. Pete waterfront ballpark a no-go|last=Gonzalez|first=Alden|date=May 22, 2009|website=RaysBaseball.com|publisher=|accessdate=2017-01-04}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Soccer specific replacement=== In 2013, the city of St. Petersburg began the process of creating a master plan for the waterfront area that includes Al Lang Stadium. Some of the proposals suggest replacing the entire stadium and surrounding parking areas with a soccer park complex with a new [[soccer-specific stadium]].{{cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/st-petersburg-creates-master-plan-for-downtown-waterfront/2139566|title=St. Petersburg creates master plan for downtown waterfront|last=Woodrow Cox|first=John|date=September 2, 2013|work=|newspaper=Tampa Bay Times|via=|accessdate=2017-01-04}} Rowdies owner Bill Edwards has stated that "in a perfect world", Al Lang Stadium would be replaced by an 18,000-seat publicly financed soccer stadium. In March 2016, St. Petersburg mayor [[Rick Kriseman]] announced plans to hold a public [[referendum]] on extending the Rowdies' lease at Al Lang Stadium and to use tax dollars to help the club transform the facility into a "city showpiece". However, these plans were shelved in May 2016, possibly because it became known that [[Orlando City SC]], the closest [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) franchise, has territorial rights for the Tampa/St. Petersburg market, clouding the prospects for potentially bringing the Rowdies to MLS and delaying the need for a larger venue.{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/growth/st-petersburg-mayor-rick-kriseman-shelves-plans-to-ask-voters-for/2275984|title=St. Petersburg Mayor Rick Kriseman shelves plans to ask voters for permission to expand Al Lang|first=Charlie|date=May 4, 2016|website=Tampa Bay Times|publisher=|accessdate=2017-01-04|author=Frago}} In December 2016, the Tampa Bay Rowdies launched another proposal entitled "#MLS2StPete" to join Major League Soccer as an [[Expansion of Major League Soccer#Tampa Bay.2FSt. Petersburg|expansion team]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/soccer/news/tampa-bay-rowdies-launch-mls-expansion-campaign/1wj2gzuw7jbbv1hroaptm1pm7j|title=Tampa Bay Rowdies launch MLS expansion campaign|last=Floyd|first=Thomas|date=December 6, 2016|work=|newspaper=Sporting News|access-date=2017-01-05|via=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.wtsp.com/sports/soccer/rowdies-announce-bid-for-joining-major-league-soccer/364393093|title=Rowdies announce bid for joining Major League Soccer|last=Hollenbeck|first=Sarah|date=December 7, 2016|work=|newspaper=WTSP|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-05|via=}} With the announcement, plans were released for an expansion and renovation of Al Lang Stadium to accommodate an 18,000-seat capacity financed by private funding.{{Cite news|url=http://patch.com/florida/stpete/rowdies-bucking-support-mls-considers-expansion-teams|title=Rowdies Bucking For Support As MLS Considers Expansion Teams|last=Lonon|first=Sherri|date=December 15, 2016|work=|newspaper=The Patch|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-05|via=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2016/12/07/tampa-bay-rowdies-mls-expansion-bid-stadium-renovation|title=Tampa Bay Rowdies launch aggressive bid to join MLS|last=Staff|first=|date=December 7, 2016|work=|newspaper=Sports Illustrated|access-date=2017-01-05|via=}} A May 2017 referendum authorized the city of St. Petersburg to negotiate a 25-year lease with the club if MLS picks the Rowdies as an expansion team.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/tampa-bay-rowdies-major-league-soccer-hopes-rest-with-st-petersburg-voters/2322337|title=St. Petersburg voters overwhelmingly bless Tampa Bay Rowdies' bid to join Major League Soccer|last=Frago|first=Charlie|date=May 2, 2017|website=Tampa Bay Times|language=en-us|access-date=2017-05-05}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/article148466969.html|title=St. Pete voters okay Tampa Bay Rowdies' bid to join MLS|last=|first=|date=May 3, 2017|work=Miami Herald|access-date=2017-05-05|language=en}}{{dead link|date=August 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.com/major-league-soccer/story/3118181/st-petersburg-approves-stadium-plan-amid-mls-expansion-bid|title=St. Petersburg approves stadium plan amid MLS expansion bid|last=Charlise|first=Jeff|date=May 3, 2017|work=ESPNFC|access-date=2017-05-05}} ==See also== * [[Rawhide (1938 film)|''Rawhide'']] – a 1938 feature film starring [[Lou Gehrig]], premiered in St. Petersburg by former Mayor Al Lang * ''[[Strategic Air Command (film)|Strategic Air Command]]'' – Al Lang Field featured prominently as the setting for the first 10 minutes of the 1955 motion picture starring [[James Stewart]] and [[June Allyson]]. The facility was the real-life spring training home for the St. Louis Cardinals at the time, and Stewart portrayed Robert "Dutch" Holland, a third baseman for the team who is recalled to active duty with the [[United States Air Force]] in the film. ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Al Lang Stadium}} * [http://www.stpete.org/allang.htm Al Lang Stadium], City of St. Petersburg official website * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080316040820/http://www.tampabay.com/specials/2008/reports/springtrain/ History of spring training in St. Petersburg] by ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' * [http://www.digitalballparks.com/SpringTraining/StPete1.html Picture tour] * [http://www.baseballpilgrimages.com/spring/stpete.html Spring training guide to Al Lang stadium] * [http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2008/St_Petersburg/St_Petersburg.htm Progress Energy Park Views – ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] * {{IMDb title|id=0048667|title=Strategic Air Command}} flagbearer = [[Héctor Méndez (boxer)|Héctor Méndez]] | rank = 12 | gold = 3 | silver = 3 | bronze = 1 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = 1900 | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Argentina]]''' competed at the '''[[1928 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]]. 81 competitors, all men, took part in 41 events in 12 sports.{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/ARG/summer/1928/ |title=Argentina at the 1928 Amsterdam Summer Games |accessdate=2010-04-23 |work=sports-reference.com}} [[Roberto Larraz]], [[Héctor Lucchetti]], [[Luis Lucchetti]] | [[Fencing at the 1928 Summer Olympics|Fencing]] | [[Fencing at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's team foil|Men's team foil]] | {{dts||7|30}} |} ==Athletics== {{main article|Athletics at the 1928 Summer Olympics}} ==Boxing== {{main article|Boxing at the 1928 Summer Olympics}} '''Men's Flyweight (– 50.8 kg)''' * [[Juan José Trillo]] ** First Round — Bye ** Second Round — Lost to [[Cuthbert Taylor]] (GBR), points
'''Men's Heavyweight (+ 79.4 kg)''' * [[Arturo Rodríguez]] → [[Image:Med 1.png]] '''Gold Medal''' ** First Round — Defeated [[Matthew Flanagan]] (IRL), KO-1 ** Quarterfinals — Defeated [[Sam Olij]] (HOL), points ** Semifinals — Defeated [[Michael Michaelsen]] (DEN), points ** Final — Defeated [[Nils Ramm]] (SWE), KO-1 ==Cycling== {{main article|Cycling at the 1928 Summer Olympics}} Six cyclists, all men, represented Argentina in 1928. ;[[Cycling at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's individual road race|Individual road race]] * [[Cosme Saavedra]] * [[Francisco Bonvehi]] * [[José López (cyclist)|José López]] * [[Luis de Meyer]] ;[[Cycling at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's team road race|Team road race]] * [[Cosme Saavedra]] * [[Francisco Bonvehi]] * [[José López (cyclist)|José López]] * [[Luis de Meyer]] ;[[Cycling at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's sprint|Sprint]] * [[Antonio Malvassi]] ;[[Cycling at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's track time trial|Time trial]] * [[Francisco Rodríguez (cyclist, born 1906)|Francisco Rodríguez]] ==Equestrian== {{main article|Equestrian at the 1928 Summer Olympics}} ==Fencing== {{main article|Fencing at the 1928 Summer Olympics}} Nine fencers, all men, represented Argentina in 1928. They won the bronze medal in the team foil event. ;[[Fencing at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's foil|Men's foil]] * [[Oscar Viñas]] ;[[Fencing at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's team foil|Men's team foil]] * [[Roberto Larraz]], [[Raúl Anganuzzi]], [[Luis Lucchetti]], [[Héctor Lucchetti]], [[Carmelo Camet]] → [[Image:Med 3.png]] '''Bronze Medal''' ;[[Fencing at the 1928 Summer Olympics – Men's épée|Men's épée]] * [[Oscar Martínez (fencer)|Oscar Martínez]] * [[Antonio Villamil]] * [[José Llauro]] ==Football== {{main article|Football at the 1928 Summer Olympics}} ;Round of 16 {{Football box |date = {{Start date|1928|5|29|df=y}} |time = 19:00 |team1 = {{fb-rt|ARG}} |score = 11–2 |report = https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/mensolympic/amsterdam1928/matches/round=197032/match=32323/index.html |team2 = {{fb|USA|1912}} |goals1 = [[Manuel Ferreira (footballer)|Ferreira]] {{goal|9||29}}

{{see also|2004 in sports|Portal:Sports}} {{Events by month|2004|in sports}}__NOTOC__ {{Month year in topic|August 2004|sports|anchor=mdy}} {| class="infobox" style="width:18em" | ==Deaths== {{main|Deaths in August 2004}} * [[August 27|27]] [[Willie Crawford]] * [[August 23|23]] [[Hank Borowy]] * [[August 16|16]] [[Ivan Hlinka]] * [[August 13|13]] [[George Yardley]] |}
==August 31, 2004== * [[Football (soccer)]]: [[Manchester United F.C.]] sign [[England national football team|England]] star [[Wayne Rooney]] from [[Everton F.C.]]. The potential fee of [[British pound|£]]27 million is the second highest ever for an exclusively British transfer. [http://uk.sports.yahoo.com/040831/2/68cx.html (Reuters)]
==August 30, 2004== * [[Football (soccer)]]: [[Newcastle United F.C.]] dismiss their manager, Sir [[Bobby Robson]], following a poor start to their [[FA Premier League|Premier League]] season and alleged discontent in the dressing room. Striker [[Alan Shearer]] is named [[caretaker manager]] and is rumoured to be Robson's permanent replacement. [http://uk.sports.yahoo.com/040830/2/6784.html (Reuters)] * [[Ice hockey]]: The [[2004 World Cup of Hockey]] begins with Finland blanking the [[Czech Republic]] 4–0 in the opening match held in [[Helsinki]]. [https://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/ap/20040831/ap_on_sp_ho_ga_su/hko_wcup_czech_republic_finland_1 (AP)]
==August 29, 2004== * [[2004 Summer Olympics]]: ** [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon|Men's Marathon]]: [[Vanderlei de Lima]] from [[Brazil at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Brazil]] is pushed into the crowd by [[Cornelius Horan]] (who ran onto the track during the [[Formula One]] [[2003 British Grand Prix]] at [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]]) while leading in the last 10 km of the race. Vanderlei loses around 15–20 seconds but finishes in third place. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/athletics/3610598.stm (BBC)] ** Gold medal winners on day 16: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/results/3534708.stm (BBC)] *** [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Athletics]] **** Men's Marathon: [[Stefano Baldini]], [[Italy at the 2004 Summer Olympics|ITA]] *** [[Boxing at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Boxing]]: **** Men's Under 48 kg: [[Yan Bhartelemy Varela]], [[Cuba at the 2004 Summer Olympics|CUB]] **** Men's 51–54 kg: [[Guillermo Rigondeaux Ortiz]], [[Cuba at the 2004 Summer Olympics|CUB]] **** Men's 57–60 kg: [[Mario Cesar Kindelan Mesa]], [[Cuba at the 2004 Summer Olympics|CUB]] **** Men's 64–69 kg: [[Bakhtiyar Artayev]], [[Kazakhstan at the 2004 Summer Olympics|KAZ]] **** Men's 75–81 kg: [[Andre Ward]], [[United States at the 2004 Summer Olympics|USA]] **** Men's Over 91 kg: [[Alexander Povetkin]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|RUS]] *** [[Handball at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Handball]]: **** Men: [[Croatia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Croatia]] **** Women: [[Denmark at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Denmark]] *** [[Gymnastics at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Gymnastics]]: **** Women's Individual All-Around Rhythmic: [[Alina Kabaeva]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|RUS]] *** [[Taekwondo at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Taekwondo]]: **** Women's Over 67 kg: [[Zhong Chen]], [[People's Republic of China at the 2004 Summer Olympics|CHN]] **** Men's Over 80 kg: [[Dae Sung Moon]], [[Korea at the 2004 Summer Olympics|KOR]] *** [[Volleyball at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Volleyball]]: **** Men: [[Brazil at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Brazil]] *** [[Water Polo at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Water Polo]]: **** Men: [[Hungary at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Hungary]] *** [[Wrestling at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Wrestling]]: **** Men's Freestyle 60 kg: [[Yandro Miguel Quintana]], [[Cuba at the 2004 Summer Olympics|CUB]] **** Men's Freestyle 74 kg: [[Buvaysa Saytiev]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|RUS]] **** Men's Freestyle 96 kg: [[Khadjimourat Gatsalov]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|RUS]] *[[Kimi Räikkönen]] wins the [[Belgian Grand Prix]] [[Formula One]] ahead of [[Michael Schumacher]], who clinches his seventh championship title. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/3609480.stm (BBC)] *[[Baseball]]: Team [[Curaçao]] beats team [[Thousand Oaks, California]], 5–2, to win the [[Little League World Series]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/news/story?id=1870825e (ESPN)]
==August 28, 2004== * [[2004 Summer Olympics]]: Gold medal winners on day 15: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/results/3534712.stm (BBC)] ** [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Athletics]]: *** Women's High Jump: [[Yelena Slesarenko]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|RUS]] *** Women's 1500 m: [[Kelly Holmes]], [[Great Britain at the 2004 Summer Olympics|GBR]] *** Men's Javelin: [[Andreas Thorkildsen]], [[Norway at the 2004 Summer Olympics|NOR]] *** Men's 800 m: [[Yuriy Borzakovskiy]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|RUS]] *** Men's 5000 m: [[Hicham El Guerrouj]], [[Morocco at the 2004 Summer Olympics|MAR]] *** Men's 4 × 100 m Relay: [[Great Britain at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Great Britain]] ([[Jason Gardener]], [[Darren Campbell]], [[Marlon Devonish]], [[Mark Lewis-Francis]]) *** Men's 4 × 400 m Relay: [[United States at the 2004 Summer Olympics|United States]] ([[Otis Harris]], [[Derrick Brew]], [[Jeremy Wariner]], [[Darold Williamson]]) *** Women's 4 × 400 m Relay: [[United States at the 2004 Summer Olympics|United States]] ([[DeeDee Trotter]], [[Monique Henderson]], [[Sanya Richards]], [[Monique Hennagan]]) ** [[Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Basketball]]: *** Men: [[Argentina at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Argentina]] *** Women: [[United States at the 2004 Summer Olympics|United States]] ** [[Boxing at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Boxing]]: *** Men's 48–51 kg: [[Yuriorkis Gamboa Toledano]]. [[Cuba at the 2004 Summer Olympics|CUB]] *** Men's 54–57 kg: [[Kim Song Guk]], [[North Korea at the 2004 Summer Olympics|PRK]] *** Men's 60–64 kg: [[Manus Boonjumnong]], [[Thailand at the 2004 Summer Olympics|THA]] *** Men's 69–75 kg: [[Gaydarbek Gaydarbekov]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|RUS]] *** Men's 81–91 kg: [[Odlanier Solís Fonte]], [[Cuba at the 2004 Summer Olympics|CUB]] ** at the 2004 Summer Olympics|People's Republic of China]] ** [[Wrestling at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Wrestling]]: *** Men's Freestyle 55 kg: [[Mavlet Batirov]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|USA]] *** Men's Freestyle 120 kg: [[Artur Taymazov]], [[Uzbekistan at the 2004 Summer Olympics|UZB]] *[[NASCAR]] [[Nextel Cup]]: [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] wins the [[Sharpie 500]] at [[Bristol Motor Speedway]]. The win is Junior's first since being badly burnt in practice for a [[Trans-Am Series|Trans-Am]] race, and comes a day after winning the [[Busch Series]] race held at the same track. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1870260 ESPN.com]

==August 21, 2004== * [[2004 Summer Olympics]]: ** [[Rowing at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Rowing]]: [[Matthew Pinsent]] wins his fourth gold in consecutive Olympics in the men's coxless four. Pinsent, [[Ed Coode]], [[James Cracknell]] and [[Steve Williams (rower)|Steve Williams]] hold off the Canadian world champions to win by 0.08s. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/rowing/3585478.stm (BBC)] ** [[Equestrian at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Equestrian]]: After an appeal to the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] by [[Great Britain at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Great Britain]], [[France at the 2004 Summer Olympics|France]] and the [[United States at the 2004 Summer Olympics|United States]], the results of the Mixed Individual and Mixed Team competitions are changed. Penalty points awarded to [[Bettina Hoy]] of [[Germany at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Germany]] for crossing the start gate twice, then removed on appeal (giving Hoy the individual gold and Germany the team gold), are reinstated. [[Leslie Law]] ([[Great Britain at the 2004 Summer Olympics|GBR]]) is awarded the individual gold, and [[France at the 2004 Summer Olympics|France]] the team gold. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/equestrian/3586618.stm (BBC)] ** Gold medal winners on day 8: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/results/3534762.stm (BBC)] *** [[Archery at 2004 Summer Olympics|CHN]] * [[Test cricket]]: [[England cricket team|England]] beat the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] by ten wickets in the fourth and final Test match, at [[The Oval]]. England have now won seven consecutive Test matches, a feat they haven't achieved for 75 years. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/england/3586826.stm (BBC)] * [[Rugby union]]: In the final match of the [[Tri Nations Series]] held in [[Durban]], the [[South Africa national rugby union team|Springboks]] (South Africa) hold off a late charge by the [[Australia national rugby union team|Wallabies]] (Australia) to win 23–19, winning the Tri Nations for the first time since 1998. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/international/3581026.stm]
==August 20, 2004== * English [[association football|football]] player [[Jonathan Woodgate]] makes a surprise move from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] to Spanish side [[Real Madrid]], for a transfer fee of £15 million. Woodgate is the second English footballer in the space of a week to sign for Real, following [[Michael Owen]]'s transfer from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. They join fellow Englishman [[David Beckham]], who has been a player at the club for a year. * [[2004 Summer Olympics]]: Gold medal winners on day 7: ==August 18, 2004== * [[2004 Summer Olympics]]: ** [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Athletics]]: [[Konstantinos Kenteris]] and [[Ekaterini Thanou]], who missed a mandatory drugs test last Thursday, withdraw from the games after an [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]] disciplinary hearing – even though the IOC chose not to take any action against them. A meeting of the [[International Association of Athletics Federations|IAAF]] on August 26 will consider whether a doping offence has been committed. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics_2004/athletics/3571944.stm (BBC)] ** [[Equestrian at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Equestrian]]: [[Bettina Hoy]] of [[Germany at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Germany]] crosses the start line twice, and is awarded penalty points. After an appeal, the points are removed. This gives Hoy the gold medal in the individual event, and Germany gold in the team event, overturned on appeal (see August 21). ** Gold medal winners on day 5: ==August 15, 2004== *[[Michael Schumacher]] wins the [[Formula One]] [[2004 Hungarian Grand Prix|Hungarian Grand Prix]], securing the constructors' championship for [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]]. Schumacher sets two driver records—12 victories in a season, and seven consecutive victories in a season. ([http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1859843 ESPN.com]) *[[PGA Championship]]: [[Vijay Singh]] wins the [[PGA Championship]] in a three-hole playoff, defeating [[Justin Leonard]] and [[Chris DiMarco]]. Singh wins his second career championship in spite of failing to shoot a birdie during regulation play in the 4th round. ([http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/pgachampionship04/news/story?id=1860011 ESPN.com]) *[[NASCAR]]: [[Tony Stewart]] wins the [[Sirius at the Glen]] race in [[Watkins Glen, New York]], despite suffering from leg and stomach cramps for most of the event. ([http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1859916 ESPN.com]) *[[2004 Summer Olympics]] **[[Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Olympic Basketball]]: The [[Puerto Rican National Basketball Team]] beats the [[Dream Team (basketball)|United States]], 92–73, recording only the third loss in Olympic competition for the U.S. team, and the first since [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] players were allowed to compete. [http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/summer04/basketball/news/story?id=1859825 (ESPN)] **[[Argentina]] beats [[Serbia and Montenegro]] 83–82 after a last-second, off-the-floor basket by [[Manu Ginóbili]], which provoked an angry outburst by Serbia-Montenegro's head coach. [http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/summer04/basketball/news/story?id=1860461 (ESPN)] **Gold medal winners on day 2: ***[[Cycling at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Cycling]]: ****Women's Road race: [[Sara Carrigan]], [[Australia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|AUS]] ***[[Fencing at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Fencing]]: ****Women's Individual Épée: [[Tímea Nagy]], [[Hungary at the 2004 Summer Olympics|HUN]] ***[[Judo at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Judo]]: ****Women's 48–52 kg: [[Dongmei Xian]], [[People's Republic of China at the 2004 Summer Olympics|CHN]] ****Men's 60–66 kg: [[Masato Uchishiba]], [[Japan at the 2004 Summer Olympics|JPN]] ***[[Shooting at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Shooting]]: ****Women's 10 m Air Pistol: [[Olena Kostevych]], [[Ukraine at the 2004 Summer Olympics|UKR]] ****Men's Trap: [[Alexei Alipov]], [[Russia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|RUS]] ***[[Swimming at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Swimming]]: ****Women's 100 m Butterfly: [[Petria Thomas]], [[Australia at the 2004 Summer Olympics|AUS]] ****Women's 400 m Freestyle: [[Laure Manaudou]], [[France at the 2004 Summer Olympics|FRA]] ****Men's 100 m Breaststroke: [[Kosuke Kitajima]], [[Japan at the 2004 Summer Olympics|JPN]] ****Men's 4 × 100 m Freestyle Relay: [[South Africa at the 2004 Summer Olympics|South Africa]] ([[Roland Mark Schoeman]], [[Lyndon Ferns]], [[Darian Townsend]], [[Ryk Neethling]]) ***[[Weightlifting at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Weightlifting]]: ****Women's 53 kg: [[Udomporn Polsak]], [[Thailand at the 2004 Summer Olympics|THA]] ****Men's 56 kg: [[Halil Mutlu]], [[Turkey at the 2004 Summer Olympics|TUR]]

Series]], held at [[Ellis Park Stadium|Ellis Park]] in [[Johannesburg]], the [[South Africa national rugby union team|Springboks]] (South Africa), behind a three-try effort by [[Marius Joubert]], defeat the [[New Zealand national rugby union team|All Blacks]] (New Zealand) 40–26. This ends the All Blacks' chances of defending their Tri Nations crown, and sets up a winner-take-all showdown on 21 August between the Boks and the [[Australia national rugby union team|Wallabies]] (Australia) in [[Durban]].
