scope="row" style="background:#000; color:#fff;"|Years ! scope="row" style="background:#000; color:#fff;"|Capacity |- ! scope="row" style="background:#eb0027; color:#fff;"|2005–2017 | 46,000{{cite news |title=USA vs. Germany friendly at RFK Stadium|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/soccer-insider/wp/2013/06/02/usa-vs-germany-friendly-at-rfk-stadium/|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=June 2, 2013|accessdate=June 2, 2013}} |} {{col-end}} ===Dimensions=== [[File:RFK Stadium satellite view.png|300px|thumb|right|Satellite view of stadium in pre-2005 soccer configuration; the darker red seats at the northwest end are not part of the current setup]] The dimensions of the baseball field were {{convert|335|ft}} down the foul lines, {{convert|380|ft|0}} to the power alleys and {{convert|408|ft}} to center field during the Senators' time. The official distances when the Nationals arrived were identical, except for two additional feet to center field. After complaints from Nationals hitters it was discovered in July 2005 that the fence had actually been put in place incorrectly, and it was {{convert|394.74|ft|1}} to the power alleys in left; {{convert|395|ft}} to the right-field power alley; and {{convert|407.83|ft|1}} to center field. The section of wall containing the {{convert|380|ft|0|adj=on}} sign was moved closer to the foul lines to more accurately represent the distance shown on the signs but no changes were made to the actual dimensions. The approximate [[elevation]] of the playing field is {{convert|10|ft|0|spell=in}} above [[sea level]]. ==Sports events== ===Baseball=== [[File:RFK Stadium baseball.JPG|thumb|300px|right|A [[Washington Nationals]] game at RFK, June 2005]] Two major league teams called RFK home, the Senators (1962–71) and the Nationals (2005–07). In between, the stadium hosted an assortment of exhibition games, old-timer games, and at least one college baseball exhibition game. In addition, from 1988 to 1991 the RFK auxiliary field served as the home stadium of the George Washington Colonials college baseball team, and hosted some Howard University and Interhigh League and D.C. Interscholastic Athletic Association championship baseball games. * April 9, 1962: The [[1962 Washington Senators season|Washington Senators]] defeated the [[1962 Detroit Tigers season|Detroit Tigers]] 4-1 in the first baseball game played at D.C. Stadium. President [[John F. Kennedy]] – the brother of the stadium′s future namesake, then-[[United States Attorney General]] Robert F. Kennedy – threw out the [[ceremonial first pitch]]. * July 10, 1962: With 45,480 in attendance, D.C. Stadium hosted its first [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star Game]], the [[1962 Major League Baseball All-Star Game (first game)|first of two]] during the {{mlby|1962}} season. President Kennedy threw out the first pitch and the [[National League]] won 3–1. * June 12, 1967: The [[1967 Washington Senators season|Senators]] defeated the [[1967 Chicago White Sox season|Chicago White Sox]] 6–5 in the longest night game to date in major league history.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=C1dYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tvcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5288%2C3447990 |work=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=(Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title=Teams battle on and on - then Solons win in 22nd |date=June 13, 1967 |page=15}} The 22-inning game lasted 6 hours and 38 minutes and ended at 2:43 a.m. EDT.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=t6lVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JeEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5615%2C2748913 |work=Eugene Register-Guard |location=(Oregon) |agency=Associated Press |title=Senators outlast Sox in 22 innings|date=June 13, 1967 |page=3B}} * April 7, 1969: With President [[Richard Nixon]] and about 45,000 on hand on Monday afternoon, rookie manager [[Ted Williams]] made his debut with the [[1969 Washington Senators season|Senators]], an 8–4 loss to the [[1969 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=obEwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wYoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=642%2C2627691|work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |agency=Associated Press |last=Polk |first=James R. |title=Ted sees spoiler role for Nats |date=April 7, 1969 |page=15}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=orEwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wYoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=739%2C2568057 |work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |agency=Associated Press |last=Nissenson |first=Herschel |title=New managers find openers little tough|date=April 8, 1969 |page=6}}{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/wire/_/section/mlb/id/7750299 |title=This Date In Baseball|first=Paul|last=Montella |date=March 29, 2012|website=ESPN.com|access-date=February 1, 2018}} * June 7, 1969: The stadium was renamed for Robert Kennedy on January 18; while the Senators were away at [[1969 Minnesota Twins season|Minnesota]], the rededication ceremony {{nowrap|was held.}} * July 23, 1969: The stadium hosted its [[1969 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|second and last All-Star Game]], a National League 9–3 victory before 45,259. Postponed by a rainout the night before, the game was on Wednesday {{nowrap|afternoon,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7N8RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=X-sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7234%2C2725766 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title=All-Star Game rained out; rescheduled this morning |date=July 23, 1969 |page=16}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=icpNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K4oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=649%2C2661503 |work=Free-Lance Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |agency=Associated Press |last=Rathet |first=Mike |title=Jackson says N.L. has more stars |date=July 24, 1969 |page=8}}}} the final MLB All-Star Game to conclude during daylight. President Nixon was scheduled to throw out the first pitch the evening before;{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iMpNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=K4oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=795%2C2456683 |work=Free-Lance Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |agency=Associated Press |last=Grimsley |first=Will |title=It's official: Nixon No. 1 fan |date=July 23, 1969 |page=8}} because of the postponement, he missed the game to personally greet the returning [[Apollo 11]] crew aboard the [[USS Hornet (CV-12)|USS ''Hornet'']].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7N8RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=X-sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6681%2C3013528 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title=Nixon heads for recovery of moon craft |date=July 24, 1969 |page=1 }} [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Spiro Agnew]] threw out the first pitch.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JXRQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NREEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7250%2C4916471 |work=Milwaukee Sentinel |last=Chapman |first=Lou |title=Bombs away! NL stars shell AL hurlers, 9-3 |date=July 24, 1969 |page=1, part 2 }} * September 30, 1971: In the [[1971 Washington Senators season|Senators']] final game (on a Thursday night), they led the [[1971 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] 7–5 with two outs in the top of the ninth. After an obese teenager ran onto the field, picked up first base, and ran off, fans stormed the field and tore up bases, grass patches, and anything else for souvenirs. Washington [[Forfeit (baseball)|forfeited]] the game, {{nowrap|9–0,{{cite book |title=Green Cathedrals |last=Lowry|first=Philip|year=2006|publisher=Walker & Company|isbn=978-0-8027-1608-8|page=239|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=Afo5vtVTz4wC|page=1}}}}}} the first forfeit in the majors in seventeen years. It was the last MLB home game at RFK until [[2005 Washington Nationals season|2005]]. * July 19, 1982: At the first [[Old-Timers' Day|Cracker Jack Old Timers Baseball Classic]] exhibition game, attended by nearly thirty thousand, 75-year-old [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Hall of Famer]] [[Luke Appling]] hit a home run against the National League's {{nowrap|[[Warren Spahn]].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=s2NRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_4oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3632%2C2473317 |work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |agency=Associated Press |last=Nelson |first=John |title=Age hasn't diminished flair for drama |date=July 20, 1982 |page=6}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EPNVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=R-IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6106%2C4694888 |work=Eugene Register-Guard |location=(Oregon) |agency=''(Washington Post)''|last=Boswell |first=Thomas |title=The best time for oldtimers |date=July 20, 1982 |page=E1}}{{cite news |title=Old timers game to be played again |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1320&dat=19821201&id=MrURAAAAIBAJ&sjid=q-kDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3360,167621|newspaper=[[Gainesville Sun]]|location=(Florida) |agency=Associated Press|date=December 1, 1982|page=5D}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=V0xSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XnsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2613%2C3881996 |work=St. Petersburg Times |location=(Florida) |agency=AP photos|title=They played just for old times' sake |date=July 20, 1982 |page=1C}}}} Although he had a .310 lifetime batting average, Appling only hit 45 home runs in 20 seasons. However, because the stadium had not been fully reconfigured, it was just {{convert|260|ft|0}} to the left-field foul pole, far shorter than normal, and Spahn applauded him as he rounded the bases. Five more Cracker Jack All Star games were hosted at RFK,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dxgiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BaYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2766%2C1093459 |work=Reading Eagle |location=(Pennsylvania) |agency=''(Baltimore Sun)'' |last=Baker |first=Kent |title=This old-timers game is a real crackerjack |date=July 1, 1984 |page=101}} until summer construction at RFK in 1988 moved it north to [[Sahlen Field|Buffalo]].{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1987/12/03/old-timers-game-moves-to-buffalo/4644b1cf-3a3c-420b-b101-943b10f3f64e/ |work=Washington Post |title=Old-timers game moves to Buffalo |date=December 3, 1987 |accessdate=May 16, 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-05-29/sports/sp-5410_1_baseball-memories |work=Los Angeles Times |agency=Associated Press |title=Glory names from baseball's past will play in Buffalo on June 20 |date=May 29, 1988 |accessdate=May 16, 2018}} During that time, Hall of Famers and stars such as [[Joe Dimaggio]], [[Bob Feller]], [[Stan Musial]], [[Hank Aaron]], [[Willie Mays]], [[Sandy Koufax]], [[Roger Maris]], [[Whitey Ford]], and Washington favorite [[Frank Howard (baseball)|Frank Howard]] would take the field. There was even a conversation about allowing then-Vice President [[George H.W. Bush]], who'd captained Yale's College World Series team, to play one year.{{cite web|last1=Appel|first1=Marty|title=CRACKER JACK OLD TIMERS GAMES|url=https://www.thenationalpastimemuseum.com/article/cracker-jack-old-timers-games|website=The National Past Time Museum|access-date=January 28, 2018}} * April 5, 1987: RFK Stadium hosted an exhibition game between the [[1987 Philadelphia Phillies season|Philadelphia Phillies]] and the [[1987 New York Mets season|New York Mets]], the first MLB game played in Washington, D.C., since a pair of exhibition games in {{mlby|1972}}. The game was a sell-out, with 45,614 tickets sold, and a crowd of 38,437 actually attended on a cold, rainy afternoon. Mets pitcher [[Sid Fernandez]] threw a one-hitter, and the Mets won, 1–0.{{cite web|url=http://ghostsofdc.org/2012/05/08/phillies-mets-rfk-stadium-1987/|title=Baseball is Back at RFK Stadium in 1987 - Ghosts of DC|date=May 8, 2012|website=GhostsOfDC.org|access-date=February 1, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1987/02/24/washingtons-baseball-morsel/d86e4801-38cf-4977-acb7-7a56e9c262de/|title=WASHINGTON'S BASEBALL MORSEL|first=THOMAS|last=BOSWELL|date=February 24, 1987|publisher=|access-date=February 1, 2018|via=www.WashingtonPost.com}} * May 6, 1989 - George Washington University defeated the Soviet national baseball 20–1.{{cite news|title=Gazuza Hurls Win Against Soviet Nine|work=The Journal News - White Plains New York|date=May 7, 1989}} * April 3, 1998: The [[1998 Baltimore Orioles season|Orioles]] and [[1998 New York Mets season|Mets]] met for the fourth exhibition game since baseball left Washington.{{cite news|last1=Justice|first1=Richard|title=ORIOLES ON SEASON'S DOORSTEP AT RFK|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1988/04/03/orioles-on-seasons-doorstep-at-rfk/5c7b991a-fa82-49b5-a28b-6fbe2aeffad0/|access-date=December 28, 2017|date=April 3, 1998}} * April 2 and 4, 1999: [[1999 Montreal Expos season|Montreal Expos]] and [[1999 St. Louis Cardinals season|St. Louis Cardinals]] met in a pair of exhibition games. The stadium was restored to its full baseball configuration for the first time since the 1971 season. Rumors already swirled that the Expos could soon call RFK home.{{cite news|title=RFK Set For Expos, Cardinals|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1999/03/28/rfk-set-for-expos-cardinals/4299ee35-2a53-47f9-801b-125f1695f8ee/|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=28 March 1999}} * April 14, 2005: The [[2005 Washington Nationals season|Washington Nationals]] (formerly the [[2004 Montreal Expos season|Montreal Expos]]) defeated the [[2005 Arizona Diamondbacks season|Arizona Diamondbacks]] 5–3 before a crowd of 45,596 in their first game in {{nowrap|Washington.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=b2BWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ePADAAAAIBAJ&pg=2646%2C3538047|work=Eugene Register-Guard |location=(Oregon) |agency=Associated Press |title=Long wait worth it for D.C. faithful |last=Fendrich |first=Howard |date=April 15, 2005 |page=C1}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wjEzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hwgGAAAAIBAJ&pg=1854%2C4706613 |work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |last=Jacobson |first=Todd |title=Nationals enjoying the view from the top |date=April 15, 2005 |page=C1}}}} President [[George W. Bush]] threw out the first pitch,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wTEzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hwgGAAAAIBAJ&pg=2528%2C4066852 |work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |last=Warters |first=Nathan |title=34 years, nine games later |date=April 14, 2005 |page=B1}} and Washington swept the three-game series to improve {{nowrap|to 8–4.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xDEzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hwgGAAAAIBAJ&pg=6095%2C5480510 |work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |last=Jacobson |first=Todd |title=Nationals break out brooms |date=April 18, 2005 |page=C1}}}} * June 18, 2006: [[2006 Washington Nationals season|Nationals]] third baseman [[Ryan Zimmerman]], who became known as "Mr. Walk-Off" for his penchant for hitting game-ending home runs, hit his first walk-off home run off [[2006 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] pitcher [[Chien-Ming Wang]] in the bottom of the ninth inning for a 3–2 Nats victory.{{cite web|url=http://m.mlb.com/cutfour/2017/10/22/259346516/top-baseball-moments-at-rfk-stadium|title=Looking back at five great baseball moments at RFK Stadium |first=Andrew |last=Mearns |date=October 22, 2017|website=Major League Baseball|access-date=February 1, 2018}} * September 16, 2006: The [[2006 Washington Nationals season|Nationals]]' [[Alfonso Soriano]] stole second base in the first inning against the [[2006 Milwaukee Brewers season|Milwaukee Brewers]] and became the fourth player to hit 40 home runs and steal 40 bases in a season.{{cite web |title=Soriano Joins Elite Group|first=Bill|last=Ladson|url=http://washington.nationals.mlb.com/news/wrap.jsp?ymd=20060916&content_id=1666470&vkey=wrapup2005&fext=.jsp&team=home|publisher=[[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]]|date=September 16, 2006|accessdate=December 24, 2011}} * September 23, 2007: The [[2007 Washington Nationals season|Nationals]] defeated the [[2007 Philadelphia Phillies season|Philadelphia Phillies]] {{nowrap|5–3}} before 40,519 in the final major league game played at RFK Stadium.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BVVVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_j4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4935%2C129451 |work=Reading Eagle |location=(Pennsylvania) |title=Phils find no relief in loss |date=September 24, 2007 |page=D1}} The win gave the Nationals an overall home record of {{winning percentage|122|121|record=y}} in three seasons at the stadium. ===Football=== RFK was the home of two professional football teams, two college football teams, a bowl game and more than one college all-star game. It hosted neutral-site college football games, various [[Historically black colleges and universities|HBCU]] games, and high school championship games.{{cite news|last1=Gildea|first1=William|title=A Day for Feasting on Football|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1986/11/27/a-day-for-feasting-on-football/5919a293-00bd-4fff-8a79-a0034d22d20f/|accessdate=20 February 2018|work=The Washington Post|date=27 November 1986}} ====Professional football==== * November 27, 1966: The [[1966 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]] beat the [[1966 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] 72–41. The 113 combined points are the most ever scored in an NFL game. * December 14, 1969: The Redskins defeat the New Orleans Saints 17-14 in what would be [[Vince Lombardi|Vince Lombardi's]] last victory. The Redskins would lose the next week at Dallas, and Lombardi would die just before the start of the 1970 season. * November 20, 1972: RFK Stadium hosts its first ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' game. The [[1972 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]] defeat the [[1972 Atlanta Falcons season|Atlanta Falcons]] 24-13. * December 31, 1972, the [[1972 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] defeat the [[1972 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] 26–3 in the [[NFC Championship Game]] to earn a trip to [[Super Bowl VII]]. * October 8, 1973: In a ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' game, [[1973 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] safety [[Ken Houston]] stops Cowboys' running back [[Walt Garrison]] at the goal line as time expired to secure a win. * December 17, 1977: The [[1977 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] defeat the [[1977 Los Angeles Rams season|Los Angeles Rams]] 17–14 in what would be head coach [[George Allen (American football coach)|George Allen]]'s final game with the team. * October 25, 1981: The [[1981 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] narrowly beat the [[1981 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]] 24–22 to earn head coach [[Joe Gibbs]] his first win at RFK Stadium. * Oct 17, 1982 First NFLPA’s all-star games during the 1982 NFL strike{{cite news|title=The scheduled 19-game round robin series involving NFL All-Stars|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1982/10/13/The-scheduled-19-game-round-robin-series-involving-NFL-All/7166403329600/|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=13 October 1982}} * January 22, 1983: The stadium physically shakes as a capacity crowd of 54,000 chants "We Want Dallas" taunting the hated Cowboys in the NFC Championship Game. The [[1982 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] go on to defeat the [[1982 Dallas Cowboys season|Cowboys]] 31–17 to earn a trip to [[Super Bowl XVII]] where they beat the [[1982 Miami Dolphins season|Miami Dolphins]] 27–17 to claim the franchise's first Super Bowl win. * March 6, 1983: The [[Washington Federals]] of the [[United States Football League]] play their first game, losing to the [[Chicago Blitz]] 28-7 before 38,007 fans at RFK stadium in the USFL's first nationally televised game.{{cite web|url=http://www.funwhileitlasted.net/2014/01/16/1983-1984-washington-federals/|title=Washington Federals, United States Football League|date=January 16, 2014|website=FunWhileItLasted.net|access-date=February 1, 2018}} The Federals never draw more than 15,000 fans again. * September 5, 1983: [[1983 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]]' rookie cornerback [[Darrell Green]] chases down [[1983 Dallas Cowboys season|Cowboys]]' running back [[Tony Dorsett]] from behind to prevent him from scoring. However, the Redskins ended up losing late in the fourth quarter. * May 6, 1984: The [[Washington Federals]] play their final game, losing in overtime to the [[Memphis Showboats]] at RFK Stadium before 4,432 fans, the smallest crowd in USFL history. * November 18, 1985: [[1985 New York Giants season|Giants]]' linebacker [[Lawrence Taylor]] sacks [[1985 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]]' quarterback [[Joe Theismann]], severely breaking his leg and ending his NFL career. Backup quarterback [[Jay Schroeder]] comes in and leads the Redskins to a 23–21 victory on ''Monday Night Football''. * January 17, 1988: Cornerback [[Darrell Green]] knocks down a [[Wade Wilson (American football)|Wade Wilson]] pass at the goal line to clinch a victory over the [[1987 Minnesota Vikings season|Minnesota Vikings]] in the NFC Championship game. The [[1987 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] go on to defeat the [[1987 Denver Broncos season|Denver Broncos]] 42–10 in [[Super Bowl XXII]]. * January 4, 1992: In a pouring rain, the [[1991 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] beat the [[1991 Atlanta Falcons season|Atlanta Falcons]] 24–7 in the Divisional round of the playoffs. After a touchdown scored by Redskins fullback [[Gerald Riggs]] with 6:32 remaining in the fourth quarter, the fans shower the field with the free yellow seat cushions given to them when they entered the stadium. * January 12, 1992: The Redskins beat the [[1991 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions]] 41–10 in the NFC Championship Game earning a trip to [[Super Bowl XXVI]] where they beat the [[1991 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]] 37–24. This was the last time the RFK held a post-season game. * December 13, 1992: Redskins' head coach [[Joe Gibbs]] coaches what would be his last win at RFK Stadium. The [[1992 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] defeat the [[1992 Dallas Cowboys season|Cowboys]] 20–17. * September 6, 1993: RFK Stadium hosts its last ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' game as the [[1993 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] open their season by defeating the [[1993 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] 35-16. * December 22, 1996: The [[1996 Washington Redskins season|Redskins]] won their last game in the stadium, defeating their arch-rivals, the [[1996 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]], 37–10. A capacity crowd of 56,454 fans watched the game, tying the football record set against the Detroit Lions in 1995. It was the last professional football game played at RFK. In a halftime ceremony, several past Redskins greats were introduced, wearing replicas of the jerseys of their time. After the game, fans storm the field and rip up chunks of grass as souvenirs. In the parking lot, fans are seen walking away with the stadium's burgundy and gold seats. =====Records===== * Most passing yards and passing TDs at RFK, Career - [[Sonny Jurgenson]], 12,985 yards, 108 TDs * Most rushing yards and rushing TDs at RFK, Career - [[John Riggins]], 3448 yards, 32 TDs * Most receiving yards at RFK, Career - [[Art Monk]], 6329 yards * Most receiving TDs at RFK, Career - [[Charley Taylor]], 42 TDs * Most passing yards, Game - [[Boomer Esiason]], 522 yards, 11/10/1996 * Most passing TDs, Game - [[Mark Rypien]], 6 TDs, 11/10/1991 * Highest quarterback rating, Game - [[Dan Marino]], 150.4, 09/02/1994 * Most rushing yards, Game - [[Gerald Riggs]], 3448 yards, 32 TDs * Most rushing TDs, Game - tie [[Earnest Byner]], [[Dick James]], [[Terry Allen (running back)|Terry Allen]], [[Joe Morris (American football)|Joe Morris]], [[John Riggins]], [[Duane Thomas]]; 3 * Most receiving yards, game - [[Anthony Allen (wide receiver)|Anthony Allen]], 255 yards, 10/04/1987 * Most receiving TDs, game - tie [[Anthony Allen (wide receiver)|Anthony Allen]], [[Gary Clark]], [[Michael Irvin]], [[Keith Jackson]], [[Del Shofner]]; 3 ====Bowl games==== * December 20, 2008: [[2008 Wake Forest Demon Deacons football team|Wake Forest]] defeats [[2008 Navy Midshipmen football team|Navy]] 29–19 in the [[2008 EagleBank Bowl|inaugural EagleBank Bowl]] before a crowd of 28,777 in the first [[bowl game]] to be played in Washington, D.C. * December 29, 2009: [[2009 UCLA Bruins football team|UCLA]] defeats [[2009 Temple Owls football team|Temple]] 30–21 before a crowd of 23,072 in the second annual [[2009 EagleBank Bowl|EagleBank Bowl]]. * December 29, 2010: [[2010 Maryland Terrapins football team|Maryland]] defeats [[2010 East Carolina Pirates football team|East Carolina]] 51–20 before a crowd of 38,062 in the [[2010 Military Bowl]], formerly the EagleBank Bowl. Great fan turnout from both universities set a bowl attendance record in Maryland coach [[Ralph Friedgen]]'s final game. * December 28, 2011: [[2011 Toledo Rockets football team|Toledo]] defeats [[2011 Air Force Falcons football team|Air Force]] 42–41 before a crowd of 25,042 in the [[2011 Military Bowl]]. * December 27, 2012: In the last Military Bowl hosted at RFK Stadium, [[2012 San Jose State Spartans football team|San Jose State]] defeats [[2012 Bowling Green Falcons football team|Bowling Green]] 29–20 in the [[2012 Military Bowl]] before a crowd of 17,835, the lowest bowl attendance figure since the [[2005 Hawaii Bowl]] had only 16,134 attendees.{{cite news|last=Solomon|first=Jon|title=Military Bowl reports college football's smallest bowl crowd in 7 years|url=http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2012/12/military_bowl_reports_college.html|access-date=December 28, 2012|newspaper=AL.com|date=December 28, 2012}} Beginning in [[2013 Military Bowl|2013]], [[Navy–Marine Corps Memorial Stadium]] in [[Annapolis, Maryland]], replaced RFK Stadium as the site of the Military Bowl. ====HBCU games==== * September 30, 1972 - Grambling beat Prairie View, 38-12. * Timmie Football Classic (1974-1975) Grambling vs. Morgan State{{cite news|title=Grambling-Morgan State Collide at RFK Stadium|work=The Pittsburgh Courier|date=6 September 1975}} * Nov 4, 1978 - Tennessee State vs North Carolina-Central faced off in an attempted reboot of the Capitol Classic, though renamed "A Touch of Greatness".{{cite news|last1=Carter|first1=Russell|title=Name Changes, Teams Same|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1978/10/31/name-changes-teams-same/70e54395-5c95-4c99-9e65-a0a0080218ef/|access-date=January 22, 2018|date=October 31, 1978}} * Nation's Capital Football Classic (1991) - Delaware State defeated Jackson State 37-34{{cite news|last1=Hente|first1=Kent|title=BISON AGAIN ENJOYING THE CLASSICS|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1991/10/04/bison-again-enjoying-the-classics/c78568b6-b06a-440e-8192-d484b2f900f4/|access-date=December 28, 2017|date=October 4, 1991}} ====College All-Star Games==== * U.S. Bowl (1962) - A college all-star game that lasted only one season. [[Galen Hall]] was the game's only MVP.{{cite news|last1=Fogg|first1=Sam|title=Hall Aerials West to 33-19 Victory|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/42310629|accessdate=22 January 2018|date=8 January 1962}} * Freedom Bowl All-Star Classic (1986){{cite news|last1=Greenberger|first1=Neil H.|title=All-Star Game Debuts at RFK|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1986/12/14/all-star-game-debuts-at-rfk/7e008c7a-83ae-4d64-91d7-93ed9e590ab3/|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=14 December 1986}} * All-America Classic (1993){{cite news|title=FOOTBALL CLASSIC AT RFK GIVES OTHERS A CHANCE|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1993/01/14/football-classic-at-rfk-gives-others-a-chance/ae064c92-92fa-450d-babe-e1c7bdf79ca3/|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=14 January 1993}} ====Neutral site games for local colleges==== * October 17, 1965: Navy beat Pitt, 12-0.{{cite news|title=Navy Blitz made Pitt 12-0 Victim|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/40441609|accessdate=22 January 2018|date=18 October 1965}} * October 17, 1970: In their 4th ever meeting, Air Force beat Navy 26-3.{{cite news|title=Frostburg Gains Sixth Straight Victory|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/21333539|accessdate=22 January 2018|work=The Morning Herald|date=19 October 1970}} * November 4, 1972: Kentucky State defeated [[University of the District of Columbia|Federal City]] 26-8, in the only football game by a UDC school.{{cite news|title=Kentucky State has talent, lacks depth|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/110070226/|accessdate=22 January 2018|date=27 August 1972}} * October 4, 1975: Navy beat Air Force, 17-0.{{cite news|title=Navy-Air Force|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/30842486|accessdate=22 January 2018|work=Hobbs Daily News|date=5 October 1975}} * November 11, 1995: [[1995 Virginia Tech Hokies football team|Virginia Tech]] clinched a share of the Big East title with a win over Temple.{{cite news|title=TWO TACKLES, VA. TECH WRAP UP PIECE OF TITLE|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1995/11/12/two-tackles-va-tech-wrap-up-piece-of-title/2655f310-8f03-4ffd-b208-59ae3f252eb3/|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=12 November 1995}} * November 11, 2000: Salisbury defeated Frostburg State, 18-8 to win the 2nd Regents Cup.{{cite web|title=REGENTS CUP GAME|url=http://www.agametailgate.com/regentscup.htm|accessdate=22 January 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160901121116/http://agametailgate.com/regentscup.htm|archivedate=September 1, 2016|df=mdy-all}} * November 10, 2001: In the only college football game at RFK to go into overtime, Frostburg State beat Salisbury 30-24 to win the 3rd Regents Cup.{{cite news|title=Football Shoots Down Salisbury in OT to Win Third Annual Regents' Cup Game|url=https://internal.frostburg.edu/home/news/university-news-portal/football-shoots-down-salisbury-in-ot-to-win-third-annual-regents-cup-game/|accessdate=22 January 2018|date=11 October 2001}} * September 30, 2017: Harvard defeated Georgetown, 41-2 in what may be the last football game at RFK.{{cite news|last1=Brooks|first1=J.|title=Georgetown football to host Harvard at RFK Stadium|url=https://wtop.com/ncaa-football/2017/08/hoya-football-host-harvard-rfk-stadium/|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=1 August 2017}} ====High schools==== RFK has occasionally hosted high school football games, but never has done so regularly.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/recruiting-insider/wp/2018/08/14/d-c-high-school-football-triple-header-set-for-rfk-stadium-in-september/?utm_term=.71a300f68e93 Pell, Samantha, "D.C. high school football triple-header set for RFK Stadium in September," washingtonpost.com, August 14, 2018 Retrieved August 18, 2018.] On August 14, 2018, DC Events announced the DC Events Kickoff Classic, a football tripleheader featuring six Washington, D.C., high schools, with games between [[Dunbar High School (Washington, D.C.)|Dunbar]] and [[Maret School|Maret]], [[Archbishop Carroll High School (Washington, D.C.)|Archbishop Carroll]] and [[Woodrow Wilson High School (Washington, D.C.)|Woodrow Wilson]], and [[Friendship Collegiate Academy Public Charter School|Friendship Collegiate Academy]] and [[H.D. Woodson High School|H. D. Woodson]]. The Classic was scheduled for September 15, 2018, and DC Events indicated that it would become an annual event if attendance at the inaugural Classic was high enough. ===Soccer=== [[File:DC United post-game victory celebration (RFK Memorial Stadium, 06-11-2004).jpg|300px|right|thumb|[[D.C. United]] after their win in the 2004 MLS Eastern Conference finals]] {{Main|D.C. United|Washington Freedom|United States men's national soccer team|United States women's national soccer team}} Although not designed for soccer, RFK Stadium, starting in the mid-1970s, became a center of American soccer, rivaled only by the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]] in [[Pasadena, California]], in terms of its history as a soccer venue.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/soccer-insider/wp/2017/10/19/soccer-at-rfk-stadium-its-dirty-and-disgusting-and-ugly-but-its-ours/|title=Perspective - American soccer made its home at aging, funky RFK Stadium|first=Steven|last=Goff|date=October 20, 2017|publisher=|access-date=February 1, 2018|via=www.WashingtonPost.com}} It is the only facility in the world to have hosted the [[FIFA World Cup]] (in [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]]), the [[FIFA Women's World Cup]] (in [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup|2003]]), [[Summer Olympic Games|Olympic]] group stages for men and women (in [[Football at the 1996 Summer Olympics|1996]]), the [[MLS Cup]] (in [[1997 Major League Soccer season|1997]], [[2000 Major League Soccer season|2000]], and [[2007 Major League Soccer season|2007]]), the [[North American Soccer League]]'s [[Soccer Bowl]] (in [[Soccer Bowl '80|1980]]) and [[CONCACAF Champions' Cup]] matches (in [[1988 CONCACAF Champions' Cup|1988]] and [[1998 CONCACAF Champions' Cup|1998]]). The [[United States men's national soccer team]] played more of its matches at RFK stadium than at any other site, and D.C. United played 347 regular-season matches there. In addition to being the home stadium of DC United, the Diplomats, the Freedom, the Whips and Team America, RFK also hosted three friendly [[Washington Darts]] games in 1970.{{cite news|title=D.C. Soccer Scheduled|work=The Federal Times|date=13 May 1970}} Notable soccer dates at the stadium include: * May 26, 1967: Professional soccer's debut game at D.C. Stadium is also the inaugural game of the new [[United Soccer Association]]. 9,403 fans show up to watch the [[Washington Whips]] lose 2-1 to the [[Cleveland Stokers]].{{cite news|title=Stokers Defeat Washington|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/17023712/|access-date=January 31, 2018|work=Medina County Gazette|date=May 27, 1967}} * July 14, 1968: [[Pelé]]'s D.C. Stadium debut, before a District record soccer crowd of 20,189 fans. Pele's Santos squad defeated the Washington Whips 3 to 1. * September 7, 1968: In a de facto Atlantic Division championship game, the Whips lost to the Atlanta Chiefs before 14,227 fans, the largest, non-exhibition home crowd in Whips history. It would be the last Whips game at D.C. Stadium. * September 19, 1970: In what we be the largest crowd to ever watch a [[Washington Darts]] match, 13,878 fans come to RFK to watch them take on [[Pelé]] and his Santos squad. They lost 7-4. The Darts also lost their two other RFK matches, against Hertha Berlin and Coventry City the prior May.{{cite web|title=Washington Darts Friendlies|url=http://www.nasljerseys.com/Friendlies/Teams/Darts%20Friendlies.htm|accessdate=5 February 2018}} * May 4, 1974: The Washington Diplomats play their first game at RFK, a 5-1 loss to the Philadelphia Atoms. 10,145 fans attend. * June 29, 1975: A District record 35,620 fans show up to see [[Pelé]] in his first game in DC with the [[New York Cosmos (1970–85)|New York Cosmos]] as they take on the Washington Diplomats. Cosmos wins 9-2. * August 6, 1977: Playing for the [[New York Cosmos (1970–85)|New York Cosmos]], [[Pelé]] plays his final regular-season game in the [[North American Soccer League]], facing the [[Washington Diplomats]] at RFK Stadium. He scores the Cosmos' only goal, but the Diplomats upset the Cosmos 2-1 before 31,283 fans.{{cite web|url=http://www.funwhileitlasted.net/2013/04/24/august-6-1977-washington-diplomats-vs-new-york-cosmos/|title=Washington Diplomats Archives • Fun While It Lasted|website=Fun While It Lasted|access-date=February 1, 2018}} * October 6, 1977: The [[United States men's national soccer team]] plays its first match at the stadium versus China. * August 19, 1979: The Diplomats drop their first-ever home playoff game to the Los Angeles Aztecs 4-1. * June 1, 1980: In a nationally televised game, before a then District record crowd of 53,351 - the largest ever for NASL game in DC - the Diplomats lose a controversial game to the Cosmos, 2–1.{{cite news|last1=Feinstein|first1=John|title=Dips Stripped of 2 Goals, Lose, 2-1, Before 53,351|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1980/06/02/dips-stripped-of-2-goals-lose-2-1-before-53351/90c423bc-dad1-42e9-bde9-60d79dedd4ca/|access-date=January 30, 2018|work=The Washington Post|date=June 2, 1980}} * August 27, 1980: The Diplomats top the [[Los Angeles Aztecs]] 1-0 in the only home playoff victory in the franchise's NASL history. * September 21, 1980: In the [[Soccer Bowl '80]], before a crowd of 50,768, the [[New York Cosmos (1971–85)|New York Cosmos]] defeat the [[Fort Lauderdale Strikers (1977–83)|Fort Lauderdale Strikers]], 3–0. * August 16, 1981: The Washington Diplomats of the [[North American Soccer League|NASL]] play their last game at RFK, a 5-1 victory over the Toronto Blizzard. * April 23, 1983: [[Team America (NASL)|Team America]], a Washington, D.C.-based [[North American Soccer League|NASL]] franchise, plays its first game, defeating the [[Seattle Sounders]] 1-0 at RFK Stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.funwhileitlasted.net/2013/12/22/1983-team-america/|title=Team America, North American Soccer League|date=December 22, 2013|website=FunWhileItLasted.net|access-date=February 1, 2018}} * June 14: 1983: 50,108 fans come to watch Team America play Fort Lauderdale followed a Beach Boys concert. The largest NASL crowd in RFK history saw Team America win 2-1 after a shootout. * September 3, 1983: Team America plays its last game, a 2-0 loss to the [[Fort Lauderdale Strikers]] at RFK Stadium. The team folds after a single season, leaving Washington, D.C., without a professional soccer franchise until 1988. * April 17, 1988: In the first professional soccer game in DC in over 4 years, the new Washington Diplomats lost 2-1 to the [[New Jersey Eagles]] in front of a crowd of just 2,451.{{cite news|last1=Huff|first1=Donald|title=Diplomats Lose, 2-1, In Opener; 2,451 Fans Watch Eagles Win at RFK|date=18 April 1988}} * June 28, 1988: The [[Washington Diplomats]] lose to [[Monarcas Morelia]] 2-1 in the first of a two-game second-round series between the teams as part of the [[1988 CONCACAF Champions' Cup|CONCACAF Champions' Cup]]. The second game, two days later, would also result in a 2-1 loss.{{cite news|last1=Freeman|first1=Mike|title=Soccer|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1988/06/29/soccer/93092864-75ae-463c-87e6-956145adee7b/|access-date=January 31, 2018|date=June 29, 1988}} * August 13, 1988: In their first ever home playoff game in the ASL, the Diplomats top the [[New Jersey Eagles]], 4-1. * August 21, 1988: In the first game of the [[1988 American Soccer League]] finals, the [[Washington Diplomats (1988–90)|Washington Diplomats]] defeat the [[Fort Lauderdale Strikers (1988–94)|Fort Lauderdale Strikers]] 5-3 before 5,745 fans at RFK Stadium. The Diplomats will defeat the Strikers again at [[Fort Lauderdale]], [[Florida]], for a surprising [[American Soccer League (1988–89)|American Soccer League]] championship in the league's first season. * June 29, 1989: The Diplomats host the ASL All-Star game, losing to the All-Stars 2-1 in front of a crowd of 4,375 * June 24, 1990: In their last game at RFK Stadium, the Diplomats lose to the Maryland Bays 4-2. Because of conflicts with concerts, they played their last two home games at RFK Stadium's auxiliary field, losing their last one 4-0 to the Miami Freedom on July 22, 1990.{{cite news|last1=Goff|first1=Stephen|title=MERGER PROPOSAL FOLLOWS DROP IN ATTENDANCE, STRAIN ON BUDGETS|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1990/06/28/merger-proposal-follows-drop-in-attendance-strain-on-budgets/1343dfad-86ae-4842-a123-6e21f46f673e/|access-date=January 31, 2018|work=The Washington Post|date=June 28, 1990}} Professional soccer would not return to RFK Stadium for more than five years. * June 13, 1993: a record-setting crowd of 54,118 show up to watch England tie Brazil 1-1 in the [[US Cup]]. * August 21, 1993: [[A.C. Milan]] defeats [[Torino F.C.]] 1–0 to win their second consecutive [[Supercoppa Italiana]]. * June 28, 1994: 53,186 fans show up to watch Italy and Mexico during the World Cup in what becomes the 6th highest attendance soccer match in RFK history. * June 29, 1994: [[Saeed Al-Owairan]] of the [[Saudi Arabia national football team]] sprints the length of the field and weaves through a maze of [[Belgium national football team]] players to score a stunning individual goal, giving [[Saudi Arabia]] a 1-0 upset victory over Belgium in [[1994 FIFA World Cup Group F|Group F of the FIFA 1994 World Cup]]. The goal later is voted the sixth-greatest [[FIFA World Cup]] goal of the 20th century. The win helps Saudi Arabia to advance to the second round of the [[FIFA World Cup]] for the first time.{{cite web|url=http://ghostsofdc.org/2012/03/25/belgium-v-saudi-arabia-94-world-cup-game-at-rfk-stadium/|title=Belgium v. Saudi Arabia: '94 World Cup Game at RFK Stadium - Ghosts of DC|date=March 25, 2012|website=GhostsOfDC.org|access-date=February 1, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/news/y=2002/m=5/news=diego-maradona-goal-voted-the-fifa-world-cup-153-goal-the-century-82406.html|title=Diego Maradona goal voted the FIFA World Cup™ Goal of the Century|first=|last=FIFA.com|date=May 30, 2002|website=FIFA.com|access-date=February 1, 2018}} * July 2, 1994: The [[1994 FIFA World Cup]] concludes its play in RFK as [[Spain national football team|Spain]] defeats [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] 3–0 in the Round of Sixteen (RFK had earlier hosted four group-play games). * June 18, 1995: In the [[U.S. Cup]] the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] defeats [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] 4-0, with goals by [[Roy Wegerle]] (3' min), [[Thomas Dooley]] (25th min), [[John Harkes]] (36' min) and [[Claudio Reyna]] (67' min). * April 20, 1996: [[D.C. United]] plays its first game at RFK Stadium, losing 2-1 to the [[LA Galaxy]]. * July 21, 1996: 45,946 fans show up to watch a group play match between Norway and Brazil in the [[Football at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|1996 Olympics Women's Soccer tournament]]. It is the largest crowd for women's sports in Washington history. Two other women's Olympic matches were played in RFK as part of the [[1996 Summer Olympics|Atlanta Olympics]]. * July 24, 1996: RFK hosted the final match for the US men's side in the [[Football at the 1996 Summer Olympics|1996 Olympics Men's Soccer tournament]]. 58,012 spectators, the largest crowd in RFK history, watched the men tie Portugal 1-1, which was not enough to advance as they needed a win. Five other men's Olympic matches were played in RFK as part of the [[1996 Summer Olympics|Atlanta Olympics]].[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1996/1996v1.pdf 1996 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 1. p. 543.{{cite news|last1=Goff|first1=Steven|title=U.S. vs. Brazil friendly at FedEx Field ranks third in attendance in Washington area, first for a national team match|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/soccer-insider/post/us-vs-brazil-friendly-at-fedex-field-ranks-third-in-attendance-in-washington-area-first-for-a-national-team-match/2012/05/31/gJQA9Jfi4U_blog.html|access-date=January 31, 2018|date=May 31, 2012}}{{cite news |last1=Constable |first1=Pamela |title=At RFK, A Home Team Sell-Out |work=The Washington Post |date=25 July 1996}} * October 30, 1996: Ten days after winning the first Major League Soccer title, [[1996 D.C. United season|D.C. United]] defeats the [[Rochester Raging Rhinos]] 3–1 in the [[Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup|U.S. Open Cup]] final, achieving the first [[Double (association football)|"double"]] in the modern American soccer era. * October 26, 1997: [[1997 D.C. United season|D.C. United]] defeats the [[Colorado Rapids]] 2–1 to win their second consecutive [[1997 MLS Cup|MLS Cup]]. 57,431 fans attend, the 2nd largest soccer crowd in DC history, and the largest for a professional league match. * August 16, 1998: D.C. United defeats [[Deportivo Toluca F.C.|CD Toluca]] of Mexico 1–0 to win the [[CONCACAF Champions' Cup]], becoming the first American team to do so and marking their first victory in an international tournament. * October 15, 2000: the [[2000 Kansas City Wizards season|Kansas City Wizards]] defeat the [[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire]] 1–0 to win their first [[MLS Cup 2000|MLS Cup]]. * April 11, 2001: [[D.C. United]] defeats [[Arnett Gardens]] 2–1 in the second leg of the [[CONCACAF Giants Cup]] quarterfinals. * April 14, 2001: The [[Washington Freedom]] defeats the [[San Jose CyberRays|Bay Area CyberRays]] 1–0 in the inaugural match of the [[Women's United Soccer Association]]. * Sept. 1, 2001: 54,282 people, the largest ever for a world cup qualifier at RFK, show up to watch the USA men vs. Honduras. * August 3, 2002: In the [[Major League Soccer All-Star Game|MLS All-Star Game]], a team of MLS players defeat the [[United States men's national soccer team|U.S. Men's National Team]] [[2002 MLS All-Star Game|3–2]]. D.C. United midfielder [[Marco Etcheverry]] is named MVP. * July 30, 2003: [[Ronaldinho]] makes his debut for [[FC Barcelona]] against [[A.C. Milan]] in a pre-season tour of the United States. Ronaldinho had a goal and an assist as Barcelona defeated defending European champion Milan 2–0 in an exhibition game that drew 45,864 to RFK Stadium.{{cite news |title=Ronaldinho Gives Glimpse|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/soccer/news/2003/07/30/barca_milan_ap/|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=July 30, 2003|accessdate=May 10, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ronaldinhosamba.com/ronaldinho_barcelona%20career_info_goal_news_new_barca_life.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104054436/http://www.ronaldinhosamba.com/ronaldinho_barcelona%20career_info_goal_news_new_barca_life.html|title=Ronaldinhosamba barcelona career life info barca report knowledge|date=24 March 2007|archivedate=4 January 2008|publisher=}} * August 2, 2003: The [[Washington Freedom]] defeat the San Jose Cyber Rays in their last game at RFK as part of WUSA. The win clinches them a playoff spot and the Freedom go on to win the last Founder's Cup, which is awarded to the winner of the post-season playoff. * September 21, 2003: RFK hosts the [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup]] opening ceremonies and first match. RFK would host six matches during the tournament. * April 3, 2004: [[Freddy Adu]] debuts with [[2004 D.C. United season|D.C. United]] at RFK with a capacity soccer crowd of 24,603.{{cite web |title=Adu Starts Well Out of the Blocks|first=Marc|last=Connolly|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=296253&root=mls&cc=5901|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=April 3, 2004|accessdate=May 10, 2014}} At age 14, Adu was, and still is, the youngest player to play in [[Major League Soccer|MLS]]. * November 6, 2004: D.C. United win the Eastern Conference final by tying the [[New England Revolution]] 3–3 and advancing on penalty kicks in what is generally regarded as one of the greatest games in MLS history. They would go on to defeat the [[2004 Kansas City Wizards season|Kansas City Wizards]] 3–2 in the [[MLS Cup 2004|MLS Cup]]. * July 31, 2004: RFK Stadium hosts its second and last [[2004 MLS All-Star Game|MLS All-Star Game]]. The East beats the West 3-2. * August 9, 2007: [[David Beckham]] debuts for the MLS [[Los Angeles Galaxy]], losing to home team [[2007 D.C. United season|D.C. United]] before a sellout crowd of 46,686 fans, the fourth largest to watch MLS at RFK Stadium. * September 2, 2009: [[2009 Seattle Sounders FC season|Seattle Sounders FC]] defeats [[2009 D.C. United season|D.C. United]] 2–1 in the [[2009 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup Final]]. This marked the first of Seattle's record-tying three consecutive [[Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup]] titles. * October 23, 2010: [[Jaime Moreno]] scores on a penalty kick in his final game as a D.C. United player to retire as the all-time leading scorer in MLS history. [[2010 D.C. United season|United]] would lose the match, 3–2, to [[2010 Toronto FC season|Toronto FC]]. * May 1, 2010: The Washington Freedom's last game at RFK, a 3-1 victory over [[Saint Louis Athletica]] * June 19, 2011: Quarterfinal of [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]], USA vs. Jamaica. US defeats Jamaica 2–0 and moves onto the Semi-Final. In the second game of the double header [[El Salvador national football team|El Salvador]] played [[Panama national football team|Panama]] to a 1–1 tie. Panama won in a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|shoot out]] in front of 46,000 people. * June 2, 2013: The [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] defeated #2 ranked [[Germany national football team|Germany]] 4–3 in a friendly commemorating the 100th anniversary of the U.S. Soccer Federation.{{cite web |title=Dempsey, U.S. Stun Germany in 7-goal Thriller|url=http://espnfc.com/news/story/_/id/1466756/dempsey-us-stun-germany-7-goal-thriller?cc=5901|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=June 2, 2013|accessdate=August 12, 2013}} * September 3, 2014: RFK hosts a triple-header on the first day of the group stage of the [[2014 Copa Centroamericana|Central American Cup USA 2014]]{{cite web|title=Central American Cup 2014 to Open in Washington, D.C. with Triple-Header|url=http://www.concacaf.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Central-American-Cup-2014-to-Open-in-Washington-D.C.-with-Triple-Header.pdf|accessdate=31 January 2018}} * October 20, 2014: The [[United States women's national soccer team]] defeats the [[Haiti women's national football team]] 6-0 in the [[2014 CONCACAF Women's Championship]], which also acts as a qualifying tournament for the [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup]]. * March 1, 2016: Querétaro eliminated D.C. United from the CONCACAF Champions League with a 1-1 tie, the last of four Champions League matches at RFK during the [[2015–16 CONCACAF Champions League|2015-2016]] season.{{cite news|last1=Goff|first1=Steven|title=D.C. United exits CONCACAF Champions League|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/dcunited/dc-united-exits-concacaf-champions-league/2016/03/01/9cfc8c22-e022-11e5-8c00-8aa03741dced_story.html|access-date=January 31, 2018|date=March 1, 2016}} * October 22, 2017: In front of 41,418 fans (the highest attendance at the stadium since David Beckham's debut game), the [[New York Red Bulls]] beat D.C. United 2-1 in United's last match at RFK Stadium. * June 10, 2018: Alianza del El Salvador defeated Olimpia de Honduras 3-1 in a friendly ====College soccer==== RFK hosted at least two college soccer games, once when Maryland moved their game there due to wet field conditions at Ludwig Field and again for a scheduled game following their national championship season. It has hosted several other Maryland games at the auxiliary field. * November 8, 1997: Maryland Terps defeated Ohio State 2-1{{cite web|title=ACC Champs End Regular Season at Home|url=http://www.umterps.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=29700&ATCLID=207268344|accessdate=28 December 2017}} * April 20, 2009: Maryland lost to Wake Forrest 3-1.{{cite news|title=Deacs Close Spring Season with 3-1 Win Against Maryland|url=http://www.wakeforestsports.com/sports/m-soccer/spec-rel/042009aaa.html|accessdate=5 March 2018|date=20 April 2009}} ====United States men's national team matches==== The [[United States men's national soccer team]] has played more games at RFK Stadium than any other stadium.{{cite web|title=U.S. Ready for 2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Quarterfinal Match Against Jamaica|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/News/Mens-National-Team/2011/06/US-Ready-for-Gold-Cup-Quarterfinal-Match-against-Jamaica.aspx|publisher=US Soccer|date=June 17, 2011|accessdate=December 24, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130045851/http://www.ussoccer.com/News/Mens-National-Team/2011/06/US-Ready-for-Gold-Cup-Quarterfinal-Match-against-Jamaica.aspx|archivedate=January 30, 2012|df=}} At times it was suggested that due to the nature of RFK and its quirkiness that it would be a suitable [[national stadium]] if US Soccer were ever to seek one out.{{cite web|title=RFK as our National Soccer Stadium|url=http://www.matchfitusa.com/2009/10/rfk-national-soccer-stadium.html|work=Match Fit USA|date=October 20, 2009|access-date=December 24, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306184251/http://www.matchfitusa.com/2009/10/rfk-national-soccer-stadium.html|archivedate=March 6, 2012|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |title=Every Big American Soccer Game Should Be Played in RFK|first=Bill|last=Simmons|authorlink=Bill Simmons|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=simmonsnflpicks/091016|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=October 16, 2009|access-date=December 24, 2011}} Several prominent members of the national team have scored at RFK, including [[Brian McBride]], [[Cobi Jones]], [[Eric Wynalda]], [[Joe-Max Moore]], [[Clint Dempsey]], [[Michael Bradley (soccer)|Michael Bradley]], and [[Landon Donovan]]. ||style="text-align:center;"|3-0||{{fb|SWI}} ||[[1994 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Netherlands vs Republic of Ireland|Round of 16]]||style="text-align:center;"|53,121 |} ===Boxing=== Late on May 22, 1993, nine thousand saw [[Riddick Bowe]] record a second-round knockout over [[Jesse Ferguson]] to retain his [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] heavyweight {{nowrap|title.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=h8VeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-jEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4066%2C2096323 |work=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=(Idaho)|agency=wire services |title=Bowe blasts Ferguson to defend title |date=May 23, 1993 |page=2B}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=t5RQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AhMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6813%2C5984567|work=Milwaukee Sentinel |agency=Associated Press |title=Ferguson no match for Bowe |date=May 24, 1993 |page=7B}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QoUyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kwcGAAAAIBAJ&pg=4735%2C4742750 |work=Free Lance-Star |location=(Fredericksburg, Virginia) |last=DeShazo |first=Steve |title=Bowe remains a puzzle |date=May 24, 1993 |page=B1}}}} On the same day [[Roy Jones]] recorded a unanimous decision over [[Bernard Hopkins]] to capture the vacant [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] middleweight title. ===Motor sports=== On July 21, 2002, the [[American Le Mans Series]] held its first event in Washington, D.C. The [[2002 Grand Prix of Washington D.C.|Grand Prix of Washington, D.C.]] was run on a temporary circuit laid out in the RFK stadium parking lot, and was the first major motor sports event held in the District of Columbia in 80 years.{{cite web |title=National Capital Grand Prix|url=http://dcpages.com/Autos/National_Grand_Prix/History/|work=DC Pages|access-date=December 24, 2011}} Prior to the race, residents living near the stadium were concerned about traffic, parking, and the noise the lengthy event would create. Citizens were outraged when they learned that District officials had ignored laws and regulations requiring an environmental impact assessment for the race, and that Le Mans officials had lied to the city about noise levels.{{cite news|last=Kovaleski|first=Serge F.|title=D.C. Panel Ignored Car Race's Environmental Impact|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 19, 2002|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Kovaleski|first=Serge F.|title=Unwillingly, Grand Prix Neighbors Off to Races|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=July 20, 2002|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Kovaleski|first=Serge F.|title=Grand Prix Firm Misled D.C. Agency On Sound Barrier|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=July 28, 2002}} Local citizens were further angered when American Le Mans racing officials reneged on a promise to remove the [[Jersey barrier]]s outlining the racecourse from stadium parking lots, leaving the unsightly structures behind and preventing the lots from being used for parking.{{cite news|last=Kovaleski|first=Serge F.|title=Car-Race Barriers Still Clog RFK Lots|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=April 3, 2003}} When the American Le Mans organization tried to hold a second race at RFK in 2003, outraged residents successfully forced D.C. officials to cancel the city's ten-year lease with the company (no more races were ever held).{{cite news|last=Kovaleski|first=Serge F.|title=D.C. Panel Blamed in Canceled Race|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=March 9, 2003|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Kovaleski|first=Serge F.|title=D.C. Agency Cancels Grand Prix Contract|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=April 5, 2003}}{{cite press release |title=National Grand Prix of Washington|url=http://www.dcwatch.com/govern/sports010809.htm|work=DC Watch|date=August 9, 2001|access-date=December 24, 2011}} ===Cycling=== The final stage of the 1992 [[Tour DuPont]] was a {{convert|14.7|mi|adj=on}} time trial from RFK to [[Rock Creek Park]] and back. [[Greg LeMond]] came in third for the stage and won the Tour, the last major win of his career.{{cite web|last1=Cranor|first1=David|title=From the Archives: The Tour de Trump comes to Arlington and Washington|url=http://www.thewashcycle.com/2016/08/from-the-archives-the-tour-de-trump-comes-to-arlington.html|website=TheWashcycle|accessdate=28 December 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/12/03/sports/03iht-bike.html|title=Greg LeMond Ending Career|first=Samuel|last=Abt|work=The New York Times|date=December 3, 1994|accessdate=April 12, 2016}} He won $50,000 and a kiss from Mayor [[Sharon Pratt Kelly]].{{cite news|last1=O'Brien|first1=Richard|title=An Uphill Victory|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1992/05/25/126566/an-uphill-victory-greg-lemond-conquered-wintergreen-mountain-and-a-topflight-field-of-cyclists-to-win-his-first-tour-du-pont|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=25 May 1992}} [[Steve Hegg]] won the stage.{{cite news|title=Tour Du Pont|work=The Gettysburg Times|date=18 May 1992}} ===Rugby=== ====Rugby union==== On 26 February 2018, it was announced that [[Wales national rugby union team]] would play a "ground-breaking fixture{{Cite news|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/rugby/rugby-news/wales-play-historic-test-match-14340042|title=Wales confirm historic match to be played in Washington DC|last=Thomas|first=Simon|date=2018-02-26|work=walesonline|access-date=2018-02-26}}" against [[South Africa national rugby union team]] at RFK Stadium on 2 June 2018. It was "Wales’ fifth test on US soil, the previous four outings all against the [[United States national rugby union team]].{{Cite news|url=http://rugbylad.ie/wales-confirm-will-play-historic-test-match-summer/|title=Wales Confirm They Will Play Historic Test Match This Summer|date=2018-02-26|work=RugbyLAD|access-date=2018-02-26|language=en-GB}}" Wales ran out winners 22-20 in front of a crowd of 21,357.{{cite web |title=Thriller At RFK As Wales Beats Boks |url=https://www.florugby.com/articles/6211627-thriller-at-rfk-as-wales-beats-boks |website=florugby}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Winner ! Score ! Opponent ! Competition ! Attendance |- | 2 June 2018 || '''{{ru|WAL}}''' || 22-20 || {{ru|South Africa}} || [[2017 mid-year rugby union internationals|2018 Wales rugby union tour of USA & Argentina]] || 21,357 |- |} ====Rugby league==== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Winner ! Score ! Opponent ! Competition ! Attendance |- | 16 March 1995 || {{flagicon|IRE|4prov}}'''[[Ireland A national rugby league team|Ireland A]]''' || 24-22 || {{rl|USA}} || [[Saint Patrick's Day Test]] || - |- | 16 March 1996 || {{flagicon|IRE|4prov}} '''Ireland A''' || 26-6 || {{rl|USA}} || [[Saint Patrick's Day Test]] || - |- |} ==Concerts== [[The Beatles]] performed a concert here in August, 1966. [[Pink Floyd]] performed a concert here on 1 June 1988 as part of their [[A Momentary Lapse of Reason Tour]] and two concets on 9 and 10 July 1994 as part of their [[The Division Bell Tour]]. From 1993 to 1999 and from 2001 to 2004, rock radio station [[WHFS (historic)|WHFS]] held its annual [[HFStival]] rock concert at RFK Stadium. On July 4, 2015, the [[Foo Fighters]] held their 20th Anniversary concert at RFK Stadium. {{hidden | headercss = background: #ccccff; font-size: 100%; width: 100%; | contentcss = text-align: left; font-size: 100%; width: 100%; | header =List of concerts | content = * [[The Beatles]] – August 15, 1966, with [[The Ronettes]] (performed in front of 32,164 fans; two weeks later, they played their last–ever concert at San Francisco's [[Candlestick Park]].Lewisohn, M: "The Complete Beatles Chronicle", pages 229–230. Harmony Books, New York, 1992.) * [[The Allman Brothers Band]] – September 20, 1970 and June 9–10, 1973, with The Grateful Dead * [[The Rolling Stones]] – July 4, 1972, with [[Stevie Wonder]] and [[Martha and the Vandellas]], September 24–25, 1989, with The [[Living Colour]] and August 1 and 3, 1994, with The [[Counting Crows]] * [[The Jackson 5]] – May 13, 1974 * The [[New Riders of the Purple Sage]] – May 19, 1974, with [[Leon Russell]] * [[Aerosmith]], [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]], [[Nazareth (band)|Nazareth]] & [[Ted Nugent]] – May 30, 1976 * [[Yes (band)|Yes]] – June 13, 1976 * [[The Beach Boys]] – June 12, 1983 * [[The Jacksons]] performed 2 concerts on September 21–22, 1984 during their [[Victory Tour (The Jacksons tour)|Victory Tour]] in front of 90,000 in total attendance of both dates. * [[Bruce Springsteen]] & The [[E Street Band]] – August 5, 1985 * The [[Grateful Dead]] – July 6–7, 1986, with [[Bob Dylan]] and [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]], July 12–13, 1989, with [[Bruce Hornsby]] & The Range, July 12, 1990, with [[Edie Brickell & New Bohemians]], June 14, 1991, with [[Dwight Yoakam]], June 20, 1992, with The [[Steve Miller Band]], June 25–26, 1993, with [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] and [[Dada (band)|Dada]], July 16–17, 1994, with [[Traffic (band)|Traffic]] and June 24–25, 1995, with Bob Dylan (the 1995 shows, occurring weeks before [[Jerry Garcia]]'s death on August 9, 1995, were among the final ten shows played by the band{{cite web|title=Grateful Dead: Listing of shows by year|url=http://www.dead.net/shows-by-year/1995}}) * [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]] – May 26, 1987 and May 19, 1992 * [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] – July 2, 1987, with [[Level 42]] * [[U2]] – September 20, 1987, with [[Steven Van Zandt|Little Steven]] & The Disciples of Soul (Due to rain, [[Bono]] fell and dislocated his shoulder, while running around during "[[Exit (U2 song)|Exit]]". He managed to finish the show, though he wore a sling for the encore and was rushed to a hospital afterwards.[http://www.u2gigs.com/show715.html U2 Washington, September 20, 1987, Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, Joshua Tree Tour - U2 on tour]. U2gigs.com. Retrieved on August 12, 2013.), August 15–16, 1992, with [[Primus (band)|Primus]] and [[The Disposable Heroes of Hiphoprisy]] and May 26, 1997, with The [[Fun Lovin' Criminals]] * [[Pink Floyd]] – June 1, 1988 and July 9–10, 1994 * The [[Monsters of Rock Tour 1988|Monsters of Rock]] Festival: June 10, 1988 * [[The Who]] – July 6–7, 1989 * [[Paul McCartney]] – July 4 and 6, 1990 * [[New Kids on the Block]] – [[The Magic Summer Tour]] – July 17, 1990 – (performed in front of 42,000 fans) * [[Metallica]] & [[Guns N' Roses]] – July 17, 1992, with [[Faith No More]] * The [[HFStival]] – July 3, 1993, May 14, 1994, June 3, 1995, June 1, 1996, May 31, 1997, May 16, 1998, September 25, 1999, May 27–28, 2001, May 25–26, 2002, May 24, 2003 and May 22, 2004 * [[Elton John]] & [[Billy Joel]] – July 20, 1994 * The [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] – September 13, 1994, with Sheryl Crow * The [[Vans Warped Tour]] – July 27, 1997, July 31, 1998 and July 27, 1999 * [[Sheryl Crow]] – October 23, 1997 * The [[Tibetan Freedom Concert]] – June 13–14, 1998 (The first day is cut short, after several fans were struck by [[lightning]], during [[Herbie Hancock]]'s set.{{cite news |title=A Flash of Fame For a Good Cause|first=Michael|last=Colton|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/daily/lightninggirl.htm|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=July 30, 1998|accessdate=May 10, 2014}}) * [[Blink-182]] – June 15, 1998 * [[George Strait]] Country Music Festival Tour – May 15, 1999 * [[The Chemical Brothers]] – September 25, 1999, with [[Everclear (band)|Everclear]] and [[Bush (band)|Bush]] * The LGBT Millennium March on Washington Equality Rocks Concert – April 30, 2000 * [[NSYNC]] – July 10, 2000, with [[Sisqó]] and [[Pink (singer)|P!nk]] and August 13, 2001, with [[Amanda (singer)|Amanda]], [[Christina Milian]] and [[Meredith Edwards (singer)|Meredith Edwards]] * The [[Dave Matthews Band]] – July 19, 2000, with [[Ben Harper]] and The Innocent Criminals and [[Ozomatli]] and June 9, 2001, with [[Angélique Kidjo]] and [[Macy Gray]] * The [[United We Stand: What More Can I Give]] Concert – October 21, 2001 (hosted by [[Michael Jackson]], as a memorial to the victims of the [[September 11 attacks]]) * Korean-American Peace Festival – June 28, 2003, with [[BoA]], [[NRG (South Korean band)|NRG]], [[Baby V.O.X.]], [[Cho Young-nam|Young-nam Cho]], [[Patty Kim]], [[Kim Gun-mo|Gun-mo Kim]], and Jo Sung-mo{{cite web|url=http://world.kbs.co.kr/english/program/program_musicnews_frame.htm?No=637¤t_page=345|title=Korean-American Peace Festival|work=KBS World|location=South Korea|publisher=Korean Broadcasting System|author=KBS|date=July 4, 2003|quote=To commemorate the centennial of Korean immigration to the United States, a music festival featuring Korean pop singers was held on June 28 at RFK Stadium in Washington, D.C. Exactly 100 years ago, scores of Koreans arrived in Hawaii, beginning the history of Korean immigration. With the number of Koreans currently residing in the U.S. exceeding one million, a series of festivals and seminars had been scheduled in both countries to celebrate and reflect on the past 100 years. Organized by the Hankook Ilbo, sister paper of The Korea Times, and the television network SBS, the concert featured scores of famous musicians such as BoA, NRG, Babyvox, Cho Young-nam, Patty Kim, Kim Gun-mo and Jo Sung-mo, under the title "Korean-American Peace Festival". The top stars visited the Korean War Veterans Memorial at the National Mall in the capital on the eve of the concert. According to The Korea Times in New York, a local daily for Korean-American society, a large number of Korean residents throughout the U.S. attended the concert and took part in a Washington, D.C. tour package, to help local travel agencies suffering from recession. The four-hour concert will be shown here in Korea on SBS on July 17, Korea's Constitution Day.|accessdate=June 12, 2015}} * The [[National ShamrockFest]] – March 10, 2007, March 15, 2008, March 14, 2009, March 13, 2010, March 12, 2011, March 24, 2012 and March 16, 2013 * The BLOCKtoberFest – October 6, 2007 * The [[DC101 Chili Cook-Off]] Concerts – May 16, 2009, May 22, 2010, May 21, 2011, May 12, 2012 and May 4, 2013 * The DAYGLOW Jam – September 30, 2011 and September 29, 2012 * The Spring Jam Festival – June 2, 2012 * [[T.I.]], [[T-Pain]], [[Young Jeezy]], [[Lloyd (singer)|Lloyd]] & [[B.o.B]] – July 4, 2012 * The Trillectro Music Festival – August 23, 2014 * [[Foo Fighters]] 20th Anniversary Blowout – July 4, 2015 }} ==Other events== * 1960–1962 – Record crowds of more than 47,000 packed the then-new D.C. Stadium on Thanksgiving Day for the City Title football game.{{cite news|last1=Manasso|first1=John|title=CITY TITLE GAME REVISITED|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1994/11/26/city-title-game-revisited/9a132379-6e80-4de1-853f-800580793946/|access-date=January 31, 2018|date=November 26, 1994}} The stadium would continue to host the city's interhigh championship game every year thereafter until the 1990s.{{cite news|last1=Payton|first1=Randolph|title=Traditional Thanksgiving Treats|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1983/11/24/traditional-thanksgiving-treats/52c9b874-1394-4e1f-9419-4d7390feca72/|access-date=January 31, 2018|date=November 24, 1983}} * May 26–27, 1995 – 52,000 men attended a two-day long [[Promise Keepers]] event. * November 27, 1997 – At an event called "Blessings '97", Reverend [[Sun Myung Moon]] and his wife, Hak Ja Han Moon, officiated over a mass wedding that drew 40,000 people including 2,500 Unification Church couples who consented to arranged marriages.{{cite web|title=Travel through time and explore the rich history of Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium.|url=http://eventsdc.com/Venues/RFKStadium/OurHistory.aspx|accessdate=26 January 2018}} * On January 19, 2009, the day before the presidential inauguration, a Day Of Service for Our Military was held at RFK Stadium as a part of the Martin Luther King Jr. National Day of Service. This was a joint operation by Serve DC and Operation Gratitude. At this event, 12,000 volunteers made over 80,000 care packages for American troops overseas.[https://web.archive.org/web/20091211022431/http://www.eaglebankbowl.org/wp-content/themes/lifestyle_40/pdf/presskit/RFKStadiumAHistoricVenue.pdf RFK Stadium – A Historic Venue]. eaglebankbowl.org * June 26, 2015 – RFK hosted the Opening Ceremony for the 2015 Police and Fire Games.{{cite news|last1=Brian|first1=Trompeter|title=World Police & Fire Games kick off at RFK Stadium|url=http://www.insidenova.com/headlines/world-police-fire-games-kick-off-at-rfk-stadium/article_a61c02fe-1c89-11e5-9207-439907787677.html|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=insidenova|date=27 June 2015}} ==In film== The stadium was prominently featured in the climax of the film ''[[X-Men: Days of Future Past]]'', released in May 2014. In the film, Magneto uses his powers to place the stadium as a barricade around the White House; the stadium is partially damaged. At the end of the film, a newspaper article announces the stadium is to begin reconstruction.{{cite web|url=http://washington.cbslocal.com/2014/05/22/x-men-movie-swings-and-misses-on-d-c-baseball-history-video/|title=X-Men Movie Swings and Misses on D.C. Baseball History (Video)|publisher=}} (RFK is shown being prepped for a baseball game; however, the movie is set in 1973, two years after the Senators left for Texas.) ==Washington Hall of Stars== :''See also [[Washington Nationals#Ring of Honor|Washington Nationals Ring of Honor]]'' During the Redskins' tenure, the Washington [[Hall of fame|Hall of Stars]] was displayed on a series of white-and-red signs hung in a ring around the stadium's mezzanine, honoring [[Sports in Washington, D.C.|D.C. sports]] greats from various sports. With the reconfiguration of the stadium, it was replaced by a series of dark-green banners over the center-field and right-field fences in order to make room for out-of-town scoreboards and advertising signage. There are 15 separate panels honoring 82 figures. [[Nationals Park]] also hosts a smaller version of the display. * Panel 1 (furthest to the left when viewed from home plate, names read there from left to right are listed from top of display to bottom): Redskins football players [[Cliff Battles]], [[Charley Taylor]], [[Bobby Mitchell]], [[Chris Hanburger]], [[Jerry Smith (American football)|Jerry Smith]], [[Len Hauss]], [[Sammy Baugh]] and [[Pat Fischer]]. * Panel 2: Redskins [[Brig Owens]], [[Larry Brown (running back)|Larry Brown]], [[Sonny Jurgensen]], team founder-owner [[George Preston Marshall|George Marshall]], [[Vince Lombardi]] (who coached them for one season before his death), [[Dave Butz]], [[Art Monk]] and [[Dick James (American football)|Dick James]]. * Panel 3: Redskins [[Vince Promuto]], [[Russ Grimm]], [[Joe Jacoby]], [[Mark Moseley]], [[Doug Williams (American football)|Doug Williams]], [[John Riggins]], coach [[George Allen (coach)|George Allen]] and [[Ken Houston]]. * Panel 4: Redskins [[Joe Theismann]], [[Billy Kilmer]], [[Wayne Millner]], [[Sam Huff]], [[Gene Brito]], [[Eddie LeBaron]], [[Charlie Justice (American football player)|Charlie Justice]] and [[Bill Dudley]]. * Panel 5: [[Edward Bennett Williams]], [[Dutch Bergman|Arthur "Dutch" Bergman]] and [[Jack Kent Cooke]]. Williams and Cooke were Redskins owners. Bergman coached in D.C. at [[The Catholic University of America]], and then ran the corporation that lobbied for the building of RFK Stadium. * Panel 6: "New Senators" manager [[Gil Hodges]], "Old Senators" player and manager [[Joe Cronin]], New Senator [[Frank Howard (baseball)|Frank Howard]], Old Senator owner [[Clark Griffith]], and Old Senators [[Goose Goslin]] and [[George Case]]. * Panel 7: [[Josh Gibson]], [[Bucky Harris]], [[Walter Johnson]], [[Chuck Hinton]], [[Eddie Yost]] and [[George Selkirk]]. Gibson played for the [[Homestead Grays]] of the [[Negro Leagues]]. Harris, Johnson and Yost played for the Old Senators. Harris also managed the Old Senators. Hinton played for the New Senators. Selkirk, who played for the Yankees, was the general manager of the New Senators. * Panel 8: "Old Senators" [[Mickey Vernon]], [[Roy Sievers]], [[Cecil Travis]], [[Early Wynn]], [[Joe Judge]], [[Harmon Killebrew]], [[Ossie Bluege]] and Grays star [[Buck Leonard|Walter "Buck" Leonard]]. Vernon also managed the New Senators. * Panel 9: Basketball figures [[Bones McKinney]], [[Red Auerbach|Arnold "Red" Auerbach]], [[Abe Pollin]], [[Bob Ferry]], [[Phil Chenier]], [[Wes Unseld]] and [[Elvin Hayes]]. McKinney played for the NBA's [[Washington Capitols]]. Auerbach played in D.C. for [[George Washington University]] and coached the Capitols. Pollin owned the [[Baltimore Bullets (1963–73)|Baltimore Bullets]] and moved them to Washington, where they became the "[[Capital Bullets]]", "[[Washington Bullets]]" and now the "[[Washington Wizards]]." He also founded the NHL's [[Washington Capitals]] and built two area arenas: The now-extinct [[Capital Centre]] in [[Landover, Maryland]] and the MCI Center (now the [[Capital One Arena]]) in downtown Washington. Ferry played for the Bullets in Baltimore and was their general manager in Washington. Chenier, Unseld and Hayes played for the Bullets in both cities. Unseld later coached them. * Panel 10: [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] swimming gold medalist [[Melissa Belote]], broadcaster [[Jim Gibbons (sportscaster)|Jim Gibbons]], and golf figures [[Lee Elder]] and [[Deane Beman]]. * Panel 11: Capitals hockey star [[Rod Langway]], tennis players [[Pauline Betz|Pauline Betz Addie]] and [[Donald Dell]], and jockey [[Raymond Workman|Sonny Workman]]. * Panel 12: Boxers [[Bob Foster (boxer)|Bobby Foster]], [[Marty Gallagher]], [[Holley Mims]], [[Sugar Ray Leonard]] and [[Steve Mamakos]]. * Panel 13: Soccer player [[Ted Chambers|Theodore "Ted" Chambers]], soccer player and coach [[Gordon Bradley]], sportswriters [[Mo Siegel|Morris "Mo" Siegel]] and [[Shirley Povich]], and [[Griffith Stadium]] and [[RFK Stadium]] public-address announcer [[Charles Brotman]]. * Panel 14: "[[9/11 attacks|Heroes of September 11th]]." To the right of Panel 15 are four banners honoring D.C. United's [[MLS Cup]] wins: 1996, 1997, 1999 and 2004. To the right of these banners is D.C. United's "Tradition of Excellence" banner, which honors [[John Harkes]] and [[Marco Etcheverry]]. To the left of those banners are four banners honoring D.C. United's [[MLS Supporters Shield]] wins: 1997, 1999, 2006 and 2007. ==Public transportation== RFK Stadium is within {{convert|1/2|mi|km}} of and easily accessible from the [[Stadium–Armory (WMATA station)|Stadium-Armory station]] of the [[Washington Metro]]. The station is served by the [[Blue Line (Washington Metro)|Blue]], [[Orange Line (Washington Metro)|Orange]], and [[Silver Line (Washington Metro)|Silver Lines]]. It is also served directly by [[Metrobus (Washington, D.C.)|Metrobus]] lines B2, D6, E32 (at Eastern High School), 96 and 97. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/22/AR2007092201033.html "Remembering RFK as a Truly Multipurpose Stadium"] (September 2007), ''The Washington Post'' ==External links== {{commons}} * {{Official website|http://eventsdc.com/Venues/RFKStadium.aspx}} * [http://www.dcunited.com/stadium D.C. United RFK Stadium page] * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000819022822/http://www.rfkstadium.com/ |date=August 19, 2000 |title=Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium }} {{Navboxes |list1= {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the [[Washington Redskins]] | years = 1961–1996 | before = [[Griffith Stadium]] | after = [[Jack Kent Cooke Stadium]] }} {{succession box | title = Home of the [[Washington Senators (1961–71)|Washington Senators]] | years = 1962–1971 | before = [[Griffith Stadium]] | after = [[Arlington Stadium]] }} {{succession box | title = Host of the [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star Game]] | years = [[1962 Major League Baseball All-Star Game (first game)|1962]] 1st Game

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{Notability|Organizations|date=November 2014}} The '''Southern Masters Cycling Club''' in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] is a [[Road bicycle racing|bicycle road racing]] club for veteran riders. Cyclists become eligible for membership at the age of 35 for males, and 30 years for females. The club is the largest Veterans cycling club in Australia. In 2006, there are over 350 members.
==History== The club's first official meeting was held on 23 March 1975. In the late seventies the Southern Veterans Cycling Club formed the Veteran Cycling Association of Victoria, which later became the [[Victorian Veterans Cycling Council]] (VVCC).<ref>[http://www.veterancycling.com.au/ Victorian Veterans Cycling Council]</ref>
The club changed its affiliation from the VVCC to [[Cycling Australia]], which is affiliated to the [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] (UCI), at a special general meeting held on 29 September 2008.<ref>[http://www.southernvets.com.au/modules/news/article.php?storyid=235 Club News : Special General Meeting], 30 September 2008</ref>
The club subsequently changed its name from ''Southern Veterans Cycling Club'' to ''Southern Masters Cycling Club''.
==Racing locations and details== The types of races the club provides are:
*[[Bicycling terminology#open road race|Open road race]], also referred to as a '''graded scratch race''' *[[Bicycling terminology#criterium|Criterium]], often abbreviated to '''crit''' *[[Bicycling terminology#handicap|Handicap]], where riders are given time handicaps in groups *'''Club Championships''', were riders are grouped according to their age (35-39, 40-44, 45-49 etc.)
Racing is conducted all year round.
In winter, racing is based around the [[Mornington Peninsula]] and [[West Gippsland]] from April to September. These races are held on public roads for which all necessary permits are obtained. Distances vary depending on the course but are generally in the range 50–80 km.
The summer season, from October to March, is [[criterium]] races, which usually last from 1 to 2 hours.
The club caters for a wide range in age and ability of competing riders with grades A to G. Riders are only grouped according to their age championship races which are held twice a year (for both the criterium and road seasons) at club, state and national level.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.southernmasters.com/ Southern Masters Cycling Club] *[http://www.cycling.org.au/ Cycling Australia] *[http://www.veterancycling.com.au/ Victorian Veterans Cycling Council]
